Cap your martini shaker and shake vigorously for thirty seconds
Serve over ice!
Enjoy!

title: Teeny Tiny Mindblowing AeroPress Recipe
description:
Ever tried a double-extraction recipe? I was inspired by @tyler.bottts and @aesirfilters to give it a go, and I had 11g coffee kicking around, so I thought I’d try making it teeny-tiny too.

The thing that blows me away with this recipe is just control you have! The straight up cup was quite bright, but being able to control the depth, then the balance was completely mind blowing.

P.S We need two carafes here.

Tried it? Let us know what you think in the comments below!
coffee: 11g, Medium-Fine (22 clicks on Comandante; 3.9 on Kinu), Any
steps:
0’00 pour 30g, give the coffee a stir, plunge out by 30s.
0’30 Remove AeroPress, take plunger off, set aside bloom (this is your sour and bitter compounds of your coffee! Kinda like a ristretto)
Reset timer. 0’00 Fill up to 120g (yes, on your coffee you just extracted), stir and wait for one minute.
1’00 Stir again, press quite slowly for 40ish seconds.
1’40 Add your coffee to your cup, and add a bit of your bloom. Taste, and if you want to make it more bitter/acidic then add more of your bloom. When you like the flavour, dilute a little (if you want) and enjoy!

title: Micro-dosing for One
description:
This is a small dose (micro-dose!) variation on James Hoffmann's AeroPress recipe.

It makes a modest cup of coffee with only 8 grams of beans.

I have small cups at home and I'm not looking for huge hits of caffeine to get me buzzed, so I developed this one cup James Hoffmann variation with one of the lowest coffee doses on this site.

It comes out really well rounded and packs a lot of flavour considering the low amount of beans used.

Recipe Note:

  • Use a dry paper filter
  • 10 clicks on the Timemore C2; 15-16 on Comandante C40

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 8g, Fine to Medium-fine, Medium roast specialty
steps:
Pour 40g of water onto the coffee and swirl until all the coffee is wet (a few seconds).
Let bloom for 10 seconds.
Pour the other 105g of water for a total of 145g.
Wait till 1:45, then swirl 3 times.
Press down very, very gently.

title: Caravan Coffee
description:
The timings are nicely defined on this recipe by Kat from Caravan Coffee

Follow the steps correctly and hopefully you will get a a bright and fruity cup with exaggerated high notes.
coffee: 20g, Slightly coarser than espresso grind, A light to medium roast with citrus undertones
steps:
First 5 seconds - pour 130 ml water over grounds (up to the #3 on the AeroPress)
:05-:30 Bloom
:30-:45 Stir/agitate
:45-:50 Pour remaining water until you reach 250 ml (#4 on AeroPress)
:50-1:30 Let it brew
1:30-2:00/2:15 Slowly plunge out your liquid gold

title: Kaldi's Recipe
description:
This AeroPress recipe by Andrew McCaslin from Kaldi's Coffee should produce a clean and juicy cup with a wonderful clarity to its flavor even given the tighter brew ratio.

For increased clarity and a cleaner cup, it's recommended to use 2 paper filters with this AeroPress recipe.
coffee: 19g, Medium - Fine, Natural process Ethiopian Coffee
steps:
Prepare 2 well rinsed paper filters.
First bloom coffee for 45 sec with 40g of water.
Fill to 281 grams after bloom.
Gently stir slurry and press at 2 min 45 sec.
Press gently for 1 min.

title: AeroPress with fruit filter
description:
Caleb shared this video on his instagram, using a slice of orange as a filter in the AeroPress.

We've seen a few fruit filter AeroPress recipes over time, but this one is easy to follow and it makes sense.

Caleb adds fruit to the serving vessel as well as making a fruit filter from a slice of orange and adding it above the paper filter in the AeroPress.

Remember to cut the orange peel off before you add it to the filter - it will fit better this way, and may also prevent some bitterness coming through from the orange peel.

Feel free to get creative with this AeroPress recipe - experiment with different types of fruit to see what works best; you could also add some ice to your vessel for a great summer coffee refresher.

For the full steps, scroll past the instagram embed :)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by 𝕔𝕒𝕝𝕖𝕓 𝕤𝕥𝕦𝕝𝕥𝕫 • カレブ (@gurucaleb) on Jun 12, 2019 at 6:45am PDT
coffee: 15g, Medium - Fine, Something nice!
steps:
Add 3 one cm thick half orange slices to the server, then a 1 cm thick whole slice on top of a filter.
Screw on the filter cap and set the AeroPress on a serving vessel.
Add the coffee grounds on top of the orange slice.
Pour 45 g water and stir gently.
Wait 45 seconds, then pour to 240 g water over 20 seconds.
Use the plunger to press firmly over about 30 seconds.
Swirl brew and pour into mug. Enjoy!

title: Coffeefusion AeroPress recipe
description:
The coffeefusion used this AeroPress recipe to win a 2nd place in the 2018 WA (Western Australia) AeroPress Championship.

To capture the floral and sweet notes from the Ethiopian beans, he used room temperature water for the bloom. This also made the final cup easy to drink, and easier to find the different flavour notes in the coffee.

Two paper filters are used in this recipe.
coffee: 19g, Coarse
steps:
Add 19g of Coarsely ground coffee to the inverted AeroPress.
Add 30g room temperature water, give it a good stir, and let it soak until 1:00.
Add 200g 99°C water, stir well and let it brew until 2:00.
Add the cap (with double paper filters), flip and press for 30s.
Give the coffee a stir, and enjoy!

title: 2017/2019 WAC Winners Hybrid for 2
description:
An Aeropress brew for two that a couple can enjoy. It's a light (low body) cup of coffee with a very sweet taste and almost no bitterness because of the short brewtime and oversaturation of the decoction.

This is our everyday brew, hybridized from the two WAC winners that we love (2017/2019) for methods, but the brew was too strong for us.

Have never measured with a refractometer for TDS.
coffee: 35g, Coarse 6.5-7/10(Baratza Encore 26 to 28/40), Medium Roast
steps:
Heat 800ml-1L water to 185 F (85 C). Do not preheat server or mugs/cups.
Pre-rinse cap with one metal + one paper filter with hot water (If using Go, use 2x paper).
Prepare inverted Aeropress with 35g coarse ground coffee (6.5-7/10).
0 Start timer and pour 150g of water over coffee for 15 sec.
0'15'' Stir vigorously but carefully with a pair of wooden chopsticks for 30 sec.
0'45'' Put the filter cap on, squeeze down to remove excess air until the cap sits just above the brew.
1'00'' Place a glass server on the scale and reset weight.
1'05'' Flip the AeroPress onto the glass server and press for 30 - 45 sec.
You should have about 110-115g of decoction. Split this evenly between two 12 oz (350 ml) capacity coffee mugs.
Top up each mug with anywhere from 150-250 ml of water, adjust to your taste. We like to top our 12 oz Kind mugs up to the "bottom" of the silicone band (about +280g of water after the decoction).

title: Simple Inverted
description:
I developed this recipe to fix a lot of the frustrations I have with most AeroPress recipes.

This one is easy to remember, hard to screw up, and includes a great trick to prevent channeling while pressing.

You can preheat the AeroPress if you want, but it's not strictly necessary.
coffee: 15g, fine, Anything that isn't dark.
steps:
Start boiling your kettle.
Place Aeropress in inverted position. You can push the plunger into the middle of the 4.
Grind 15g of coffee just finer than you would for a small v60, then add to the aeropress
When your kettle has boiled, immediately pour all 200g of water into the aeropress. Don't let it cool.
Stir three times and let it steep until 1:00.
At 1:00, stir 3 more times, scraping off any coffee stuck on the plunger.
Press all the excess air out of the chamber and flip the aeoropress onto your cup.
Lift up the aeropress an inch or two, and drop it back onto the cup to collapse any potential channels.
Press slowly, taking about 30 seconds.
Drink end enjoy.

title: The shake-weight
description:
This recipe for me gives me good complexity and depth, and most of all it’s fun to do (just not in front of people)!

I recommend 2 filter papers!

(Side tip, dose coffee with the AeroPress at an angle, tap once and wipe the fines off the side for a cleaner brew!)

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think in the comments below!
coffee: 14g, Medium coarse, Something Light & bright
steps:
Add 14g of coffee to your AeroPress.
Dose your water and put on the plunger.
Immediately grab your AeroPress with one hand, use thumb and index finger to pull up and create a vacuum which prevents your coffee from dripping through.
Swirl like mad! (For 30-40 sec.)
At 1 min, plunge for 40 seconds.
Drank!

title: Extra Chocolatey Full Bodied Cup
description:
Just like the name, this recipe will give you a chocolatey full-bodied cup of coffee.

This AeroPress recipe uses room temperature water for blooming and hot water for the rest of the brewing.

75ml cold water - around 18-24°C (65-75°F);

200-250ml hot water - 88-90°C (190-195°F);

It is also recommended to use 2 filters for this recipe.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 21g, Medium to Medium-fine (15 on Baratza Encore), Any. I used Half-Calf from Tony's Coffee.
steps:
0-0:10: Add 75mL of 21°C cold water
0:11-0:25: Let the coffee bloom
0:26-0:45: Add 200mL of 88°C hot water
0:46-1:05: Stir consistently
1:06-1:45: Insert plunger slightly and pull out a bit to create a vacuum; let it brew
1:46-2:00: Press coffee into a mug
Add between 25mL-50mL of hot water if it's too strong for your taste

title: Tetsu Kasuya AeroPress Recipe
description:
A unique take on using the AeroPress as a brewer, essentially using it to make a pour-over.

This AeroPress recipe is also a great option to make a larger volume of coffee.

*Tetsu Kasuya uses 2 paper filters to achieve a cleaner cup.

**If you use dark roast beans, use lower temperature water around 82C°-85C°.

Watch a detailed video of the recipe being made by Tetsu Kasuya here:

https://www.instagram.com/tv/CORkSoaiNoO/?igshid=1xiq2ov3mpxo2

_____________________________

If you'd like to watch a short version of the walkthrough video, check out this one from @kofe.ino on Instagram:

https://www.instagram.com/tv/CO0OdSThv_8/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link

Have you tried Tetsu's recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 20g, Medium, Light
steps:
Pour 40g to bloom until 00:30
Pour gently in short pulses (eg. pulses of 40g) until 3:00
Finish pouring all 300g by 3 minutes
Plunge for 20 seconds, stop at the hiss
Serve & enjoy!

title: 15g that made me happier
description:
A twist on the most popular recipe on the site -- 13g that makes you happy

This recipe gives you a larger cup of coffee with a similar flavour to the recipe that inspired it.

If you try this recipe, let us all know what you think in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, Coarse (18 clicks on Timemore C2), Anything
steps:
Prep the AeroPress in the inverted position with as little of the plunger inserted as you feel comfortable with.
Prep a wetted double paper filter.
Add the ground coffee, shake to level.
Add 35g of water.
Stir until mixed - roughly 7 times.
Start timer. Wait until 0:30.
At 0:30 pour water until the AeroPress is full, roughly 250g total.
Stir 20x.
At 1:40 flip AeroPress and press slowly for 1 minute, finishing around 2:40.
After emptying out and cleaning your AeroPress (roughly 30s) enjoy!

title: Vietnamese Iced Coffee
description:
Vietnamese iced coffee (Cà Phê Sữa Đá) is known for its sweetness and complexity from its one secret ingredient: sweetened condensed milk.

This recipe recommends using a dark roast coffee with a smoky characteristic (the author uses Hayes Valley Espresso from Blue Bottle).

Try to use a brand of condensed milk from an Asian supermarket (e.g. Longevity Sweetened Condensed Milk).
coffee: 17g, Fine, Dark roast with a smoky character (I use Hayes Valley Espresso from Blue Bottle)
steps:
Invert the AeroPress. Pre-wet a paper filter in cap.
Start a timer, add 90mL and stir to wet the grounds.
Wait to 2 minutes.
Cap the AeroPress, invert and plunge gently for about 30 seconds.
Stir in about 1 teaspoon of condensed milk, add ice, and enjoy!

title: Long but lovely
description:
This AeroPress recipe is a twist on James Hoffmans french press recipe.

It's a slow AeroPress recipe with a long steep time (takes about 10 minutes in total)... if you have the patience, give it a try - you might be pleasantly surprised!

I use double paper filter for this one but you don't have to.
coffee: 15g, Medium - Fine, Something nice!
steps:
Grind 15gm of coffee, about medium-fine
Preheat all your equipment in warm water
Add 45ml of water and gently stir 3 times back to front, and let it bloom for about 30seconds
Slowly pour remaining 195ml of water
Let sit with the cap on until 4 minute mark
After 4 minutes, gently stir 3 times back to front again
Screw the cap back on, and let sit for another 6 minutes
Flip and press slowly into your pre-warmed cup
Give the coffee a final good stir
Enjoy!

title: Uncle Wolfie's 'CocoSpresso'
description:
Your coffee grounds bloomed in espresso then steeped in coconut water?

It sounds crazy at first glance but give this one a shot (actually a double shot... of espresso).

This is not your typical off the shelf AeroPress recipe, but who needs typical - let's have some fun. If you're keen to try something different, something creative (or simply don't want to sleep for a few days) put this on your list. It's a sure crowd pleaser.

In the words of Uncle Wolfie himself, this one is " rich and Smooth, like a hunk of fudge ".
coffee: 19g, Medium - Fine, A coffee with red berry and rich chocolate notes. And most house espressos.
steps:
Add your coffee to the AeroPress.
Prepare a doubleshot espresso using the same coffee.
Pour the espresso into your AeroPress, using it to bloom the coffee that is already in there for about 10 seconds.
Top up with 250g of coconut water
Add plunger (but don't push) to top of AeroPress to stop it dripping.
Steep for 45 seconds.
Remove plunger, stir briefly, and then plunge for approx. 25 seconds.
Enjoy the ride!

title: Championship Cold Water Bypass
description:
I crafted this recipe for the 2019 Canadian National Aeropress competition.

It intentionally makes use of some room temperature water in a creative way to bring the cup down to drinking temperature quickly for judges to taste.

It'll work at home too and allow you to drink it right away!
coffee: 25g, Medium/Fine, Any naturally processed coffee or full bodied washed.
steps:
Rinse two paper filters with room temperature water
Pour 20g room temperature water into a shot glass
Preheat water to 85°C
Grind coffee and dose into inverted Aeropress set around the 3 mark
Pour 50g of water and agitate thoroughly with stir stick for 20 sec.
Pour 100g of water and cap
Press Aeropress lightly until all the air has been removed from the chamber
Flip at 1:00 and press steadily for 30 sec. into a room temperature serving vessel
Bypass with 80g of 85° water and stir
Add your final 20g of room temperature water and stir

title: Sweet Town
description:
This is the experimental AeroPress recipe that I use for my best coffee every day. It is the best I have ever tried!

This recipe gives me a wild taste with a well-rounded body, tea-like and very smooth,

It produces a ready to drink coffee with enhanced sweetness, citric acidity, balanced, clean after taste.

  • There is an interesting twist at the end where you top up with 88°C water and 60g of room temperature water.
  • Use double rinsed paper filters for this recipe.

Taste result using a Full Washed Bali Arca Ulian:

Aroma: Earl Grey Tea, lemon citrus,

Flavour: tangerine orange, mango, ginger, cotton candy, molasses, hints of melted white cocoa.

Body: well rounded, mild, smooth and clean after taste.
coffee: 24g, Medium coarse, Light roast
steps:
Add 24g of coffee into chamber.
Add 60g of water in 15 seconds.
Stir gently for 15 seconds.
At 0:30 put filter cap (with double rinsed paper filters) in chamber.
Wait for 30 seconds.
At 01:00 invert the AeroPress, swirl, and press for 30 seconds.
Top up with 100g of 88°C water and 60g of room temperature water.
Enjoy!!

title: Cardamom Coffee
description:
Pure coffee by itself can be great and, undoubtedly, it is never reaching the goal to get the "Platonic ideal" cup of coffee, while randomly or more or less systemically sampling the landscape of varying parameters.

But, it doesn’t mean that sometimes we are allowed to sin by adding some additional flavour to the coffee. This recipe is an example of an Aeropress adaptation of such a sin - adding a *cardamom taste *to the coffee, as people sometimes do in the East.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, Medium-fine, Light or medium dark roast
steps:
Grind 15g of coffee together with 2-3 cardamom seeds (I use 10 clicks at Porlex Mini)
Preheat the AeroPress and set it in inverted position, add grounded coffee
Add 30g of 96C (204F) water and stir 10x
At 30s add water up to 180g and stir 5x
Wait till 1:30
Flip AeroPress and press for 1 minute till 02:30.
Wait 30s and serve.

title: Some serious gourmet s**t
description:
This AeroPress recipe takes approximately 6 minutes to brew. It requires minimal agitation, apart from a quick swirl to break the crust half-way through.

Although it requires some patience and attention, the result is worth the effort.

Have you tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 14g, Medium-coarse (21 clicks on Timemore C2), Light to medium
steps:
Bloom the coffee with 60g water for about 45 seconds.
Pour the rest of 190g water and let it brew for 3:40 min (around 4:25 since start of timer).
Swirl the AeroPress 3 times and remove the crust.
Let it rest for about 1:30 min (around 6:00 on the timer).
Invert the aeropress and very slowly press it. Might take about 1 minute.
Enjoy your brew.

title: Ralf Rueller's Personal AeroPress Recipe
description:
This is the AeroPress recipe of The Barn Founder, Ralf Rueller.

It aims for a juicy cup that has a creamy mouth feeling.
coffee: 15g, Medium (26 clicks on Comandante), Something light
steps:
Rinse paper filter(s) (use two for a cleaner brew).
Invert the AeroPress (below number 4) and fill in the coffee.
Aim for 40-50mL with 30 seconds bloom (V60 Style).
Stir about 5 times.
After 30 seconds pour in the rest of the water.
At 01:00 attach the filter and gently push out the air.
At 01:30 flip the AeroPress.
Give it a slow press (around 20s).
Enjoy!

title: 2022 World AeroPress Championship - 1st Place
description:
T﻿his is the winning AeroPress recipe by Jibbi Little of Australia from the 2022 World AeroPress Championships, held in Canada.

T﻿here are a couple of new techniques from 22's WAC winning recipe that you will find interesting.

Firstly, Jibbi does a double grind for her beans. The first grind is in a very coarse setting s﻿o you can blow out the silver skins easily. After the second grind, she also sifted out the fines to reduce the bitterness that often comes from over-extracted fines grounds.

S﻿econdly, she used 4 iced chilling balls to cool down the brew at the pressing phase. This will give you a smooth mouthfeel.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • D﻿ouble grind: 1st grind very coarse with Timemore; 2nd grind setting 4 with Kinu Classic (around medium-fine); If you use washed process, grind slightly finer
  • B﻿low out the silver skins after the 1st grind
  • S﻿ift out fines (100-200 microns) if you can
  • J﻿ibbi used Perfect Coffee Water in the competition
  • 1﻿ rinsed paper filter
  • U﻿se a spoon with a small bowl to stir
  • B﻿ypass to 150g
  • Aim for TDS of 1.3 – 1.35
  • Optional: use extract chilled ice balls (3 at the bottom and 1 on top, a total of 4). It will give you a smooth mouthfeel. Use this before the bypass

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 18g, Medium-fine (Setting 4 on Kinu Classic), Natural, Striped Red Bourbon (from Colombia Finca Juan Martin)
steps:
Follow the 2-step grind process to prepare your beans.
Pour 94ml of water and stir 35 times gently.
At 1:20 screw on cap and press out remaining air.
At 1:30 flip and press onto your iced chilling balls for 30 seconds from 1:40 - 2:10.
You will have about 58-64g of concentrate.
Bypass 90°C water to 150g.
Enjoy!

title: An 'Espresso like' coffee
description:
This recipe produces an almost espresso-like drink that tastes great on its own, but opens up very nicely when diluted.

High Dose, low water, lots of agitation - if you use the right kind of bean this recipe will hopefully produce a full bodied, round, super sweet and super tangy coffee.
coffee: 32g, Fine, Something bright, lightly roasted, fruit forward
steps:
Add coffee to chamber in standard orientation
Pour the full 100g of water into the chamber
Stir for 10 full seconds
Plunge for 20 seconds

title: The Corvus
description:
This is a high volume AeroPress recipe that should produce a balanced and silky cup (or two!) of coffee.

Suggested to use a bright single origin, but blends can also produce good results - experiment and see what works best for you!
coffee: 20g, Medium - Fine, A bright single origin
steps:
Setup your AeroPress in standard orientation.
Add your coffee.
Add 60gm of water.
Bloom and stir, for 30 seconds .
Pour remaining water quickly to 283g and insert the plunger (but don't plunge).
Slowly start plunging at 3:00
Add 75g water.

title: The Tinkerer
description:
“This recipe produces a super consistent, medium/full bodied cup. For more fruit forward or floral coffees, I'll usually add a tiny bit of water to open up the cup slightly....

...this recipe is pretty versatile, but I really dig it with washed Ethiopian and Guatemalan coffees.”
coffee: 21g, Medium, Ethiopian or Guatemalan
steps:
Add 50g water and bloom for 20-30 seconds.
Fill to 150g.
Stir for 20-30 seconds.
Fill to 270g.
Slow and steady plunge.
For more fruit forward or floral coffees, you can add a tiny bit of water to open up the cup slightly.
Enjoy!

title: Aeropress Number 4
description:
This recipe is not about scales, it’s about good tasting coffee by using the numbers on the Aeropress.

Ca. 17g= Heaped Aeropress scoop!

When I got a new coffee, I start by grind it on the finer side of medium. If the coffee is too bitter go coarser at the next try. Do this step by step until you find the right grind.

Tip: Let your coffee cool down for a awhile. The taste of your coffee changes depending on the temperature.

Enjoy!
coffee: 17g, Medium, Whatever you like, but keep it fresh
steps:
Rinse your paper filter.
Heat up your cup and Aeropress with hot water.
Put your 17g of coffee (heaped Aeropress scoop) in your Aeropress.
Bloom: add water until all of the coffee is wet, slew it around or give it a quick stir.
Wait until 30sec. , than put in water until number 4 on the Aeropress.
Stir 3 times.
Insert plunger to prevent water dripping through.
At 1:30 take of the plunger an stir for 3 times.
Insert plunger and press. This should take around 30sec.
Enjoy!

title: Fellow Prismo HUGE Espresso-style Shot
description:
I just like these BIG espresso styled shots with a nice crema on top. The recipe is similar to the recommended Fellow Prismo recipe but uses the double amount of water and coffee. I use 13 clicks on the Commandante and it works well for me.

I would love to get your feedback on this recipe, so please leave a comment below.
coffee: 40gg, fine, something like espresso grind size, dark espresso roast
steps:
Grind 40g fresh roasted coffee (1-2 weeks makes best crema).
Preheat your AP with the Prismo attachement screwed on.
Use fresh filtered water just off the boil.
Then add your coffee to the AP.
Start the timer and pour slowly 100g of water (takes you 10-20 secs).
Now stir like crazy for 20-30 seconds (I like to go with 25 secs).
When the timer hits the one minute mark, put the AP on a mug or thick glass and put the plunger on.
Now press very hard at the beginning, to compress the puck and keep pressing hard and even till the plunger reaches the coffee bed.
You should get a nice crema (should last at least 30 secs, if it doesn't maybe the coffee beans were not fresh enough or your pressing was to weak or stirring not long enough).
Now give your coffee a stir and enjoy!

title: Crocodile Prophecy
description:
"A fragrant and dynamic tumble of flavours."

This what you get when you combine coffee, saffron and a little bit of diet Pepsi.

This recipe is an interesting one - we look forward to hearing what you think in the comments below!
coffee: 25g, fine, medium roast - something fruity and spicy
steps:
Place coffee grounds into an inverted AeroPress and wet two paper filters
Pour in just enough water to cover grounds
Stir three times and steep for thirty seconds
Add one large pinch (about .05g) saffron
Pour cold Diet Pepsi slowly to reduce head and adequately fill. Fill to about the "1" mark on your AeroPress.
Stir in a circular motion for about thirty seconds, then wait ten minutes
Put on cap with filters, flip, and press slowly into mug. Plunge all the way through

title: Ice brew for the summer
description:
Need an iced coffee for this summer? This recipe makes lemonade-like chilled coffee by using light roast beans with fruity notes.

You need 130g of ice cubes for brewing. After brewing, pour coffee into another vessel before serving into a glass - this will mix the coffee liquid well with the melting ice.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 21g, Medium (20 clicks on Comandante C40), A fruity 86+ light roast
steps:
Rinse your filter
Add 130g of ice cubes into your brewing vessel
Put your AeroPress on top of the vessel and fill it with the coffee
Add all of the water and give your brew a good stir with a spoon
Insert your plunger in a 30° angle and pull it up a little to create a vacuum
Wait till 1:45 and press, finish at 2:00
Pour your brewed coffee into another vessel to mix it
Serve it in a glass while it is still cold. Enjoy!

title: Aeroespresso
description:
I did in no way, shape or form invent this recipe nor do I take any credit. This is just a fusion of different recipes I've tried and what has gotten me the results I was looking for.

It's truly simple. Two paper filters - one under the grounds, one on top of the grounds. No stirring is needed. Press as hard as you can. Voilà!

P.S. The water temperature range is for the different levels of roast - 80°C for very dark roast, and then the lighter the roast, the higher the temperature.

Pro tip: If it is too hard to plunge, coarsen up the grounds.
coffee: 18g, Fine (11 clicks on Timemore C2), Any coffee that would work for espresso
steps:
Put in filter and screw on cap
Put in coffee grounds and shake to settle
Put second filter in on grounds and gently tamp with makeshift tamper (easiest way to do this is to wet the filter and attach it to surface of what ever you are using to tamp with)
Pour in water and let it sit for about 10 seconds
Plunge like there is no tomorrow and Enjoy!

title: 15g of Fine Robusta
description:
Robusta beans are typically known for their bitter notes and have a reputation as being undesirable compared to Arabica in the specialty coffee world.

This AeroPress recipe will help take your cup of Robusta from sour and bitter to balanced, sweet and mostly you will avoid getting an under-extracted cup.

If you feel that your coffee needs more or less extraction, just wait more or less 30s at step 5.
coffee: 15g, medium, Fine Robusta Medium - Medium Dark
steps:
Prepare your AeroPress in the inverted position
Add your coffee ground (I use TimemoreC2, 15-16 clicks), use 1 paper filter (u can use 2 for less oily cup)
Blooming - add 30g water, stir 10x, wait until 30s
At 30s, pour water until 180g, then stir 5x
Wait until 2m (30s blooming + 1:30s)
Flip your AeroPress, then press for 30s, should finish at around 2:30s
Wait 20-30s then serve and enjoy your cup

title: Coffee with April
description: April coffee is a coffee shop and roastery in Copenhagen. The recipe yields a light and juicy coffee with low bitterness and good acidity.
coffee: 13g, Medium-Coarse(25-27 clicks on Comandante), Kenyan or Ethiopian
steps:
Put the paper filter in, rinse it and put it on the standard position. Pour the coffee in.
Pour 50g of water in quickly, stir it a little, put the piston on to avoid dripping and wait till 0:30.
Remove the piston, pour the remaining 150g of water in.
Put the piston on, let it sit to 1:30.
Press down slowly until 2:00, stop at the hiss.

title: 2021 World AeroPress Championship - 2nd Place
description:
This is the 2021 World AeroPress Championship 2nd place, recipe by Maru Mallee.

In the words of Maru, via his Instagram:

I wanted to share the recipe I submitted to the World AeroPress Championships, that got me 🥈 2nd place.

I hope people enjoy it, but remember that any competition recipe is dialed in specifically for the type of beans being used, so if you are going to use this recipe with different beans, please be ready to adjust the variables for a good extraction.

Some additional details for his recipe:

📍This recipe uses 1 rinsed paper filter.

GRIND: #23clicks (Comandante Grinder)

WATER: 150ml @93C + 36ml ROOMTEMP bypass

WATER TYPE: 75% classic + 25% distilled

BREW TIME: 1:50 + 20sec press

Tried it? Let us know what you think in the comments below!
coffee: 18g, Medium (23clicks on Comandante), Light (Pablo Bamaca)
steps:
0:00-0:12 Pour 150ml water @93C over the grinds.
0:12-0:25 Stir firmly x20.
0:25-0:30 Attach filter cap to brewer, press out any excess air, and place carafe on top.
1:50-1:55 Flip carafe and brewer, swirl x3 and tap down x2 (like a rao-spin).
1:55-2:15 Press, plunger should touch coffee puck with gentle pressure, but don't force.
2:15-2:20 Remove brewer and shake it gently, letting any last drops of coffee into the carafe.
Add 36ml room temperature water as a bypass. Swirl the brew to cool, and serve.

title: Nothing Too Fancy
description:
This simple recipe is best suited for the morning brew or when you are in a rush.

Simple. But delicious.

Tried this AeroPress recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below!
coffee: 15g, Med/corse, Med roast
steps:
Bloom 15g coffee with 30g water for 30 sec (stir once up and down)
@ 30sec Add 190g water & stir once up & down
@ 1:30 start to plunge
Plunge for 30 sec
Enjoy!

title: Tried & True
description: After trying multiple recipes from all over the internet, champions and aeroprecipe, nothing beats simplicity for me. Its the way the AP was intended to be used!
coffee: 14g, Fine, Any!
steps:
Grind your coffee very fine (1 click out on a Hario Slim Mill)
Heat water to specific degrees based on roast (195f for Dark Roast,200f for Medium, 205f for light roast)
Rinse filter and place in aeropress, set it up in standard formation on your vessel
Add ground coffee to your aeropress
Fill water to the space between the 1 and the 2 and vigorously stir for 10 seconds
Insert your plunger and press for about 45 seconds. The slower the better so you get a cleaner cup
Add water to taste

title: Balanced Starbucks Dark Roast
description:
This recipe has the perfect balance of chocolate, fruit and bitterness without being overpowering, heavy and burnt.

*Optional* Add excess hot water to taste for strength but this recipe is fairly well balanced for my taste.
coffee: 18g, medium, Starbucks Dark Roast (any variety)
steps:
Place 2 AeroPress filter papers into basket, and place basket onto cup.
Place 18g coffee into inverted Aeropress, with plunger set to (4). Pre-heating not required.
Take water off boil and let rest 10 seconds.
Rinse filter paper in basket (on top of cup) with 50 mL hot water. This preheats and rinses.
Start timer, and pour hot water into Aeropress chamber to the top within 30 sec.
Spiritedly stir with spoon for then next 30 seconds. Place filter and basket on top.
At 1:45, flip Aeropress over onto cup and press down on plunger over the next 30-60 sec.
Stir coffee in cup, and enjoy!

title: Quick and dirty
description:
This is based off me sifting through countless recipes, and finally just throwing my hands up and doing things myself. I have no real knowledge as to what happens when coffee is brewed, I just know what I like, and I like this cup. Maybe you will too!

I don't have a proper kettle or temp, just a scale and a timer, and, if done right, will give you a nice, full-bodied, not-too-bitter morning cup.

I like to add a splash (~20g) of room temp water just to bring it to the perfect sipping temp. This cup is great with or without milk. I hope you like it as much as I do!
coffee: 19g, 2 steps coarser than espresso, Darker side of med-dark roast
steps:
Put your 19g of ground (I use a medium-dark blend from a local roaster, just a bit more coarse than espresso) into an inverted Aeropress--tap to level out.
Bloom- Once the water has boiled, give it about 30 seconds. Start your timer. Pour 35g of water in, enough to saturate the grounds, and give 3 quick stirs.
Let it sit and bubble off until you hit 35 seconds.
Fill up the Aeropress to just below the top with your water, and give a quick 3 stirs with a chopstick or reusable straw (something that won't slosh it around too much).
Top off with water, throw on the metal filter, screw on the cap, and flip it onto your cup. Give it an authoritative, but forgiving press that should last about 30-35 seconds.

title: 2019 Cataluña AeroPress Championship - 3rd place
description: 2019 Cataluña AC 3rd place AeroPress recipe by Cristian Povedano.
coffee: 30g, Medium-Fine, Kenya
steps:
Grind your coffee
Add it to your Inverted Aeropress, shake to level
From 0:00 to 0:10, add 120g of water
From 0:10 to 0:40, stir.
At 0:40, put filter cap (with pre-wet filter) in place
At 0:50, flip the AeroPress and start pressing
At 1:20, stop pressing. You should have now 75-80ml of the concentrated drink
Add 120 of 85°c water.
Stir with the Cupping Spoon to lower the temperature.

title: Orange AeroPress Coffee
description:
Here is another refreshing orange AeroPress recipe. It's perfect for a hot summer day.

Giii prefers to use coffee beans with bright acidity for this recipe. She uses one paper filter and one sliced orange filter - the paper filter goes into the cap first, then the orange filter.

Try to find the right thickness of the orange filter before the brew. Make sure the cap can be screwed onto the AeroPress.

** For the final coffee, you can also add some orange juice or orange syrup to the coffee for more refreshing deliciousness.

(Photo Credit: @giii_muu )

Watch a detailed video of the recipe being made here:

https://www.instagram.com/p/CPFW8nrhOjA/?utm\_source=ig\_web\_copy\_link

Have you tried Giii's recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 18g, Fine - 4 on Porlex mini, Beans with bright acidity
steps:
Prep: Place a wet paper filter on the cap. Place a sliced ​​orange on the paper. Put 100g of ice in a server.
Add 30g of hot water, stir well and bloom for 30 seconds.
Add the remaining 90g of hot water, stir a little, let it steep for 1 minute.
Put the cap on, flip the AeroPress onto the server. Press for 1 minute.
Pour the coffee into a glass with ice, and finally put an ​​orange slice in the glass.
Enjoy!

title: Taking you to flavourtown
description:
My first recipe! I've taken some inspiration from some of my favorites I've found on the site and merged them together as best as I possibly can. The result is a coffee which I love the flavours and body, for not much effort or need for extra equipment.

There's a little bit of wiggle room in the recipe, including upping the dose and keeping ratios consistent if you want a bigger cup. You can also use this inverted if you want a slightly richer body.

Hope you enjoy!

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 14g, Medium-fine, Any, but I've especially enjoyed with washed Rwandan
steps:
Set up your AeroPress with a dry paper filter on a cup with coffee grounds.
Start timer for bloom, add around 28g of water to the AeroPress for a 1:2 ratio.
Either use the provided stirrer to wet all the grounds, or give the Press a swirl (I prefer this personally).
Let timer hit 0:45, then add your remaining water for a total 200g, place the plunger on top to avoid dripping.
At 1:45, give the AeroPress a swirl, once or twice is enough, and place back down.
At 2:15, start pressing, going all the way through past the hiss so the plunger is at the bottom, aiming to finish by 2:45.
Let coffee cool for 30s-2m, and enjoy!

title: Delightful light roasts
description:
A great AeroPress recipe for light roasts and high extraction.

I am using the coffee Migu by 19grams, but it should work with many light roasts, especially those anaerobic processed beans.

Take note of step 3 - the special stirring technique.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 20g, Fine, Migu, anaerobic, light roasts
steps:
Add 20g of finely ground coffee in the inverted AeroPress.
Add 70ml of water and start the timer.
Stir for 30s from left to right to top to bottom (like a cross) and end with a vortex.
Add the remaining water, then let it sit for 60s and add the filter cap.
Flip it onto your cup and press for around 30s.

title: Counterintuitive Sweet Spot 12'
description:
This AeroPress recipe was created by a group of coffee lovers from Brazil. The group is called **DDUCL \(Diário de um Coffee Lover** \- [check them out on Instagram](https://instagram.com/diariodeumcoffeelover)\).

It is a very interesting recipe that takes 12 minutes, with a stir every two minutes.

Be patient and you'll be rewarded with a delicious, full-bodied cup of coffee.

Hope you enjoy!

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 17g, Fine (espresso), Medium roast
steps:
Add 230mL of water at 89°C to the coffee.
At every two minutes, stir 4x slowly.
At 12:00, stir 4x slowly for the last time.
Flip and press slowly for about 1 min.
Enjoy!

title: Sunday Coffee with Your Partner - 2 Cups
description:
This recipe brews 2 cups of coffee - great for sharing with your partner on a Sunday morning.

The coffee has great body and sweetness.

📝 R﻿ecipe Notes:

  • G﻿rind size is medium-fine (15 clicks Comandante)
  • P﻿aper filter, rinsed
  • 2﻿40g of water for brewing, 160g for bypass

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 24g, Medium-Fine (15 clicks Comandante), All kinds
steps:
Start the timer and pour 240g water.
Wait until 0:30 then stir 3 times.
Put the plunger on and wait until 2:30.
At 2:30, swirl 3 times and immediately plunge for about 30 seconds.
Add 160g water.
Enjoy your Sunday with your partner.

title: Alan Adler in his kitchen
description:
During the filming of the Aeropress Movie, the crew got to hang out with Alan Adler (inventor of the Aeropress) in his home kitchen and make a brew on the Aeropress!

This is the recipe he used.

" I never made peace with the biterness of coffee... and I just really got to love coffee a lot more when I learned how to brew it without bitterness this way "

Alan doesn't measure the beans on a scale in this recipe, but we are estimating about 14gm per scoop.

Props to European Coffee Trip for sharing this video - if you haven't already, checkout the Aeropress Movie for the interesting history of the Aeropress.
coffee: 15g, Fine, Whatever suits your fancy
steps:
Put the filter in the cap
Put the cap on the chamber
Alan likes to use a clear mug so he can see the flow
Add 1 1/2 Aeropress scoops of finely ground (espresso grind) coffee to the chamber
Give the chamber a shake or a tap to level the coffee
Add the water slowly up to the number 2
Stir for about 10 seconds, mixing the coffee and water
Insert plunger
Use the weight of your arm to slowly press the coffee through for about 20-30 seconds
For american style coffee, top up the mug with hot water to taste

title: DIY Cold Drip using the AeroPress
description:
Setting up a professional cold drip operation at home might not be on your wishlist due to time and costs, but this recipe is proof you can achieve something pretty good at the expense of a 600mL water bottle.

Follow this recipe for a brew that is refreshing, rich in flavour and delicious.

The recipe recommends a coarse grind, but feel free to experiment for different results. Beware the finer your grind it will typically take longer for all the water to drip through.

If you like what you can achieve with this recipe and want the process to be a bit simpler next time, take a look at the _PUCKPUCK recipe._
coffee: 55g, Coarse
steps:
Add your paper filter to the AeroPress cap and rinse thoroughly before placing the AeroPress upright on top of a caraffe (or vessel that holds about 500mL water)
Coarsely grind 55gm of coffee, add it to your chamber and give it a good tap to level out the bed of coffee
Add a filter paper to the top of the bed of ground coffee. The filter paper helps distribute the water. (This step isn't essential so don't worry too much).
Grab your bottle and tip the water into your vessel. Don’t throw this water out - we will use it for the brew. Cut the bottom of the bottle off. Leave the lid on.
Place the bottle (lid down) into the chamber.
Add 600ml of water to the bottle (the water we saved earlier)
Now the tricky part. By unscrewing the lid slightly we should be able create a drip rate.
We want the drip rate to be about 1 drip per second. You probably need to check the drip rate after about 20 minutes.
When you get your drip rate running well let the water drip away. Check it every now and then to make sure everything is ok.
Once the water is finished you should have a rich and delicious cold drip coffee.

title: Rich Flavour Daily Cup
description:
This recipe is an adapted version of 2019 WAC winner Wendelien Van Bunnik.

On the basis of Wendelien's recipe and approach, I've established my own recipe which I use daily (tastes good both with paper & metal filters).

My grind is 2 clicks on Rhinowares Grinder.

Temperature is always off-the-boil.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below!
coffee: 16g, Fine, Kenya 86+
steps:
Grind 16g of coffee (Fine).
Relatively quickly add 140 ml of water.
Stir 14 times (for 10 seconds).
Put the cap with a filter on and push out the excess air. Brew for 1:05 (experiment with brew time further).
Invert and press for 15-20 secs.
Enjoy!

title: 2018 World AeroPress Championship - 2nd place
description: Runner up recipe by Xiaobo Zhang, representing China at the 2018 World AeroPress Championship in Sydney.
coffee: 31g, Quite coarse, Kirinyaga, Kenya (as used in the 2018 WAC Finals)
steps:
Add 30g of coffee into chamber.
Add 100g of water in 15 sec.
Stir for 15 sec.
Add 70g of water.
Add 1g of very finely ground coffee (like espresso).
Attach filter cap, flip the AeroPress and press for 45 sec.
Top up brew with 50g of water.
Enjoy.

title: The Magpie
description:
Mark recommends using the inverted method with 30g of coffee beans.

The larger dose of coffee, combined with a coarser grind setting and a bypass at the end achieves a really nice, light and clean cup.

If you have no shortage of beans, give it a try!
coffee: 30g, Coarse, Any light/medium roasted coffee
steps:
Add 30g of coarse ground coffee to inverted AeroPress
Add 120g water to coffee grounds
Agitate vigorously for 10 seconds
Wait 40 seconds
Flip, press for 20 seconds
Add the remaining 120g water to coffee

title: A hint of liquorice
description:
This AeroPress recipe strays a little from the norm; if you are not a liquorice lover, look away.... but if you like liquorice and you like coffee, this experimental AeroPress recipe might be right up your alley.

For this AeroPress recipe it's best to use a balanced medium body coffee with a dark chocolate base and a hint of caramel - this would complement the aniseed and not overpower it.

The result should be the same bold texture and flavour profile you expect from the AeroPress, yet with a hint of liquorice to excite the palate and give it an unexpected twist.
coffee: 22g, Fine - Medium, A balanced medium body coffee with a dark chocolate base and a hint of caramel
steps:
Add a sprinkle of Aniseed to ground coffee
Add coffee mixture and fill the water level to nearly the top (number 4 marker)
Wait for the bloom or "mushroom cloud" to dissipate (which is approx. 30 sec)
Stir the coffee for it to begin settling
Add more water back to the number 4 marker
Place the plunger on top, and plunge after 3 more minutes of brewing
We recommend using a reusable metal filter to enhance the oil viscosity and texture of the coffee; as well, it's good for the environment to save paper

title: Great cup. Cheap price.
description:
This AeroPress recipe was made thinking on the readily available, sometimes almost stale, very dark and cheap roasts. This type of coffee is the one you find at Walmart’s, Mexican supermarkets, etc...

Also, this works with a blade grinder, if like me, you can’t really afford a great burr grinder.

Tasting notes, on the coffee I used, which was Gila Master Blend, are almost banana like, a bit chocolate as well. But a very clean cup and a not so intrusive after taste.
coffee: 22g, Fine-medium fine (granulated sugar like), Very dark roasts, cheap, whole grain
steps:
Measure and grind 22 grams of coffee
Boil around 600ml of water
Prepare the AeroPress over a cup with 2 filters
Add boiling water to the press up to number 3. Note: you haven’t added the coffee to the press yet
Let the water run down the filters while it heats the Aeropress
Once the water is done running down empty the cup below the AeroPress and put the coffee into the press, set it over the cup again.
Pour ~150grams of 80-85° water to the press and start the timer immediately
Stir vigorously for ~5seconds
At the 45s mark add ~40grams of 80-85°C water and stir slowly for 2 seconds
At 1:10 begin pressing, you want to be done in about 20 seconds (~1:30 mark), but stop as soon as the hissing starts. You may dilute the end result with up to 60grams of water

title: Candy Blow Flower AeroPress Recipe
description:
Inspired by Alan Adler and Tim Wendelboe's AeroPress recipes, I have tried to mix it with this recipe for full washed beans.

The result is a clean cup with a double sweet taste and balanced acidity.

By cross stirring slowly 15 times before steeping and waiting 15 sec before the press decreases the extraction rate, hence reducing acidity and enhancing the creamy body in lower temperature water.

It works well with full washed beans.

This is a delicious AeroPress recipe you can drink 10 minutes before you go to work as it has a soft and mild taste to drink with strong caffeine. It's just drinkable - enjoy!!

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think in the comments below!
coffee: 25g, Coarse (7/10), Light, washed process
steps:
25g of coffee into chamber.
Add 50g of water in 10 seconds.
Stir gently and slowly for 20 seconds, about 15 times.
At 0:30 add 50g (rest of the water) in 10 seconds.
Put filter cap on and wait for 15 seconds.
At 0:55 invert your AeroPress and press gently for 30 seconds.
Bypass with 145g water at 80°C.
Enjoy!!

title: The Dayglow
description:
Tohm Ifergan from Dayglow coffee shares with us an AeroPress recipe that brings out the bright acidity and fruitiness from African beans.

The result should be well balanced with pleasant acidity - a nice clean cup.
coffee: 18g, Slightly finer than Medium - Fine, African/ Wet-Process
steps:
Pre wet 2 filters
Dose 18g of coffee into an inverted AeroPress
Bloom with 60g water
Agitate for 10 seconds
At 30 second mark, fill to 250 grams, cap and steep until 1:00
Agitate for 5 seconds
Flip, and press for 60 seconds
Decant

title: Long steady press
description:
I created this recipe to achieve a balaced, delicate body but complex taste (not heavy and bitter).

This recipe uses 2 standard filters.

No stirring, no bloom - only a swirl at the end.

Let me know what you thinkin the comments below ;)
coffee: 15g, Medium fine - 21 clicks on Comandante grinder, Any light roasted beans
steps:
Put 2 filters into the cap. Don’t rinse or preheat the brewer
Add your coffee ground (15g-16g)
Pour all the water, making sure you wet all the coffee and place the plunger(put it from an angle) immediately so the coffee doesn’t drip
Wait until 1:30
At 1:30 gently swirl the brewer hold it all so it doesn’t make a mess
Press very slowly for 1 minute - make sure the water moves down at the same pace
Wait till the coffee reaches a drinkable temperature - 45 degrees
Enjoy! Observe how the coffee tastes differently at different temperatures

title: Blue Bottle Recipe
description:
This is the standard recommended recipe from Blue Bottle for brewing a great cup with little-to-no fuss.

If you like a stronger tasting brew, add 2-3 grams more coffee.

Have you tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, Medium - Fine, Light / Medium
steps:
Rinse filter with hot water
Invert your aeropress and dump coffee
Start timer and add 30g of hot water (around 200F)
Stir slightly to saturate all grounds and let it sit for 30 sec
Add the rest of the water in
After 1 minute has elapsed, stir 10 times to agitate
Place cap, invert and press.
Your brew should finish around 1:30 to 1:45

title: MokaPress
description:
Whilst trying some espresso-style AeroPress recipes I casually found a nice Moka-pot style coffee, which is really quite indistinguishable from a good Moka Pot technique. It's not burned, which is good, since in Italy nearly everyone burns its coffee with a Moka Pot, making it quite bitter.

The coffee is quite strong (but not like espresso, obv) and I think, with some tinkering, it could be made more enjoyable.

  • This recipe works for 2 doses. I think you can make more servings (max 4, or 3 on an AeroPress go) by adding half a spoon of coffee for every serving.
  • You may also use a Moka filter or a shower screen, but it's not strictly needed
coffee: 20g, ground for Moka, Dark roast
steps:
Add a filter paper to the bottom and add your ground coffee, then shake it to level the bed.
Compress the puck in some way (usually a small spice bottle is ok) and then put a paper filter on the puck (or a shower screen of a moka filter).
Add your water (if you can't measure it, up to the 2) and press gently. Stop at the first drops.
Wait 25 seconds to pre-infuse the puck.
Then, press gently. You can stop at the hiss or press to the puck, it does not change a lot.
Enjoy your strong small coffee.

title: 2021 World AeroPress Championship - 3rd Place
description:
This is the 2021 World AeroPress Championship 3rd place, recipe by Brandon Smith of South Africa.

A couple of interesting facts about Brandon's WAC experience, via Brandon's instagram:

1. This is my first time ever competing in any coffee competition so I'm stoked to be placed 3rd in the world 🥉🌍

2. Due to delays with shipping and customs in South Africa, I only received the coffee after the championship was already over 🤯 This means I had to use a different coffee to craft a recipe and hope for the best, I'd say that 3rd in the world is not bad at all!

Some additional recipe details:

WATER: 140g @88C + 80g @75C bypass

BREW TIME: 2:00 + 1:30 cool down

Have you tried it? Let us know your thoughts in the comments!
coffee: 18g, Medium-fine (18clicks on Comandante), Light
steps:
Start timer as coffee hits the grounds. 140g single pour in 10 secs with 88C° water.
Place kettle down to the side and take the lid off.
Stir from front to back 5x gently with AeroPress stirrer.
Rinse 1 paper filter and place cap on.
Press until the air is out.
At 1:25 flip onto a cup and swirl once.
At 1:30 start pressing for 30 secs through the hiss.
Bypass with 80g water at 75C°.
Transfer into a decanter and serve into cups.
Let stand for 1min30sec and serve.

title: 2021 Swedish AeroPress Championship - 1st Place
description:
I used this recipe to win the 2021 Swedish AeroPress championship.

I have been experimenting with cold and hot water - this recipe uses both. Big inspiration is Coffeefusion. Thanks!!

Preparation:

  • 20-45 grams cold water in a syringe. How much water depends on the coffee you use
  • 2 papperfilters or 1 Aesirfilter
  • Boiling water 210 grams

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 18g, Medium to course, Any filter coffee
steps:
18 gr of coffee in the AeroPress.
Spray it with 20-45 grams of cold water.
Just press the coffee under the water.
00.45 add 210 grams of hot water.
Just break the surface if the coffee is fresh.
At 01.50 put on the lid.
At 02.00 press slowly for 45 seconds.
Swirl the coffee between two jugs.
Serve and enjoy!!

title: Hello Darkness, My Old Friend
description:
I wanted a daily driver for my morning coffee and I'm a fan of dark roasts.

This should produce a nicely balanced coffee with a good mix of bitterness and acidity. A perfect way to start your day.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below 👇
coffee: 12.5g, Medium-Coarse, Dark
steps:
Set up Aeropress in Inverted orientation on scale, pour in ground coffee.
Start time and slowly pour in 205g of water
At 1:00, stir coffee inside the Aeropress (3 times clockwise, 3 times counterclockwise)
Rinse paper filter and attach filter cap. Allow coffee to brew until 2:30
At 2:30, flip the Aeropress onto cup
Press very slowly until plunger reaches bottom around 3:30
Enjoy!

title: Roastown Coffee: An Inverted Daily Driver
description:
I came across this on bilibili, YouTube’s Chinese equivalent.

Y﻿ou can view the video here. 


As an inverted recipe, it hits all the right spots: low-dose, no fuss, time-efficient.  

Jason of Roastown Coffee created this recipe as a response to “championship” recipes. Popularized by WACs of recent years, these recipes typically use high doses (e.g., 30g) and bypass. Although punchier in flavor, they just can't function as daily drivers. 

I always found washed light roasts hard to dial in on the AeroPress, yet Jason’s recipe blew me away.

Recipe Notes:

  • Grind size: In the video, Jason recommends the same grind size as a cupping. For me, a medium-fine grind size works very well; #22-24 on C40 might be a good starting point.
  • Ratio: 1:18 or ~55g/L (same as James Hoffmann’s recipe)
  • Jason also suggests lowering acidity by dropping your water temperature.

I think this recipe can suit a wide range of roasts and processing. For lighter roasts, I always perfer my water straight off the boil. If you are brewing a darker roast, try grinding coarser, using more coffee and lowering your water temperature.

T﻿ried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 12g, Medium (Cupping), Light Roast
steps:
Set inverted AeroPress at full capacity (plunger below ④ marker)
Boil your water, grind 12g of coffee and add to chamber. Pre-wet your filter-cap combo.
Start a timer, quickly add ~216g water in one pour.
Stir continuously until about 0:40.
Twist on cap with filter and let sit.
Optional: Gently swirl the AeroPress a few times to further de-gas, then slowly push out extra air in the chamber. (this makes flipping drip-free)
Flip at 1:30.
Optional: If any grounds are still stuck to the piston/wall, gently swirl to knock off. (this maximizes extraction during percolation)
Press gently all the way, finishing at about 2:00.
Enjoy!

title: Espresso-like AeroPress
description: An espresso-like AeroPress using chocolatey medium roast coffee.
coffee: 18g, Medium-fine, Any chocolatey medium roast
steps:
Add 30g of water to bloom, stir thoroughly.
At 30s, add 60g of water.
Stir 10 times straight.
Attach filter cap.
Start pressing at 1:50 for 15s.

title: Minimal with Prismo
description:
This is specifically for light roasted beans. I used beans from Blue Tokai Riverdale Estate Fruit Pack (All 3 variants of Grape, Red Fruit & Papaya Fermentation).

Keeping here 3 minutes total brewing time as per James Hoffmann's method.

The goal is to brew decent coffee of 150ml from 12-14 gram Coffee.
coffee: 13g, Medium-Fine, Light roast. I used Fermented Beans from Riverdale Estate Yercaud, India
steps:
Setup Aeropress in standard position with Fellow Prismo Metal Filter attached. Put your 13gm grounds in it.
Start your stopwatch and add approximately 70-80ml water in it (little above the (1) mark). Give a gentle stir to mix grounds well with water. You will see a slight layer of crema on top.
After 2 minute add 70-80ml of water in it and wait for 1 more minute.
After 1 minute, use plunger and press it all the way through.
Enjoy a delightful cup of black coffee.

title: AeroPress / V60 Combo
description:
This one sounds odd, but bear with us. You'll need an AeroPress and a V60, and you'll be plunging the Aeropress into the V60.

This AeroPress Recipe should produce a super full-bodied, but balanced coffee, with the aromatic acids and sugars.

In Tylers own words:

" thiswasjust me wanting to have a cup of coffee with next to no emulsion in it haha "
coffee: 14g, Medium - Fine, Topeca Coffee Roasters Kenya Gachichi PB!
steps:
Invert the press to where the plunger is on the bottom of the upside-down notch "4"
Place coffee in AeroPress
Pour 50g water onto grounds, stir vigorously to incorporate water into grounds. (At this point, you'll rinse the AeroPress filter and the V60 filter.)
At the :30 mark, pour the remaining 160g water
Set the cap on top of the press, but don't seal it
At 2:30, stir the coffee again, place cap on and seal it
Set Aeropress on top of v60 cone and place cone on cup
Press out the coffee through cone and filter
Decant into your favorite mug

title: HG Personal AeroPress
description:
Flavor notes

“While the volume of the drink is low I appreciate the almost espresso-like extraction with the heavy body and oily consistency of pulling from a machine. If you're going for a quick punch of caffeine the Aeropress is a joyous beverage creator.”

Suggested Coffee

“Obviously coffee that's the freshest roast date possible, de-gassed about 4 days. My personal preference is a single origin that is flavorful at a City+ to Full City. Lighter roasted coffee's are great fun with the Aeropress but I find the taste goes a little sour for my liking.”

Method

The exact instruction on the manual inside the AeroPress box. With a little modification to the ratio.
coffee: 20g, Espresso Fine, Freshest possible.
steps:
Add coffee to chamber and level out the grounds by giving it a shake
Start timer, add 241ml of water
Stir for 10 seconds
Place plunger into the chamber and pull up slightly to create vacuum
Let sit until 1:45, then plunge for 30 seconds
Sip right away for strong cup. Add some water for a more traditional cup. Enjoy!

title: Brooklyn Roasting Company
description:
This AeroPress recipe brews a high volume cup with a complex, balanced mouth feel that a metal filter allow to come through.

"This is my go to brewing method on sourcing trips every origin & process. With minor adjustments for the specific coffee (mostly with the amount of coffee)."
coffee: 18g, A little finer than Medium - Fine
steps:
Bloom with 100 grams of water.
Stir.
Add additional 150 grams of water.
Stir.
Screw the metal filter cap on.
Add 50 grams of water to a previously warmed cup [to dilute]
Invert and press.

title: Amazing Acidity & Body
description:
"I designed this recipe to produce a high acidity & body with light sweetness & low bitterness**."**

This AeroPress recipe is modelled after cupping techniques and the flavours you'll get out of this really depend on the coffee.

I prefer to use a coffee from Ethiopia or Kenya in which case you might get notes of lemon, dried strawberries, stone fruits and jasmine

This AeroPress recipe employs the use of WPM ZD-10T
coffee: 35g, 4 in WPM ZD-10T, ethiopian-Rei(roast in iran)
steps:
Grind 35gm of coffee.
Preheat and pre-wet your paper filter and the AeroPress chamber
Place the AeroPress on top of your mug in the standard position. Add your coffee
Start your timer
0 - 30 seconds --> add 90gr hot water at 90°C
30 - 40 seconds --> stir(6x) and rest
40 - 60 seconds --> add 50gr hot water at 90°C
1:00 - 1:05 --> Place the plunger back on
1:05 - 1:35 --> press slowly! Once you hear the hiss, STOP your press
and finally add 50gr hot water in 79°C (bypass) . enjoy

title: Market Lane AeroPress
description:
This is a nice and simple of brewing an AeroPress, complete with video, thanks to the team at Market Lane Coffee.

As any simple recipe goes, feel free to experiment a bit here with the amount of coffee used and how much you stir - the more you stir the stronger your coffee will be.
coffee: 15g, Medium - Coarse, Something nice and fresh
steps:
Pre-rinse your paper filter
Pre-warm your AeroPress
Grind your beans (15g, but feel free to experiment) at a medium level
Add your coffee to your AeroPress in the inverted orientation and tare the scale to zero
Add 200ml water and wait until 1 minute
Stir (you don't need to be too gentle, but the more you stir the stronger it will taste)
At 1:30 add your cap, flip the AeroPress and start plunging
At about 2:00 it should be complete
Enjoy!

title: 2017 World AeroPress Championship - 2nd place
description:
Yusuke Narisawa won the 2nd place at 2017 World AeroPress Championships in Seoul, Korea with this recipe.

It's an interesting recipe because he used two kinds of coffee grounds - 28g coarse grounds and 1.5g very fine grounds. Also, double paper filters have been used to achieve a cleaner cup.
coffee: 29.5g, Coarse (with a sprinkle of fine grounds), Light to medium roast
steps:
Add coffee to the inverted AeroPress
Tare the scale and start timer
Add 70g water and stir 20 times
Add 100g water
Put filter cap (with wet double paper filter) in place and flip the AeroPress
Press slowly until 1:50
Add 75g hot water

title: 2019 Irish AeroPress Championship - 1st place
description:
Stephen Houston is like royalty in the Irish coffee world - he has previously been the brewers cup champion and is the current Irish AeroPress champion (2019).

Stephen is the head roaster at Bailies Coffee in Belfast and we are lucky enough for him to share the recipe he used in the 2019 World AeroPress championship finals.

Try it out, and share your thoughts in the comments below!
coffee: 35g, 32 clicks on a comandante, Washed Ecuador (or any Central American)
steps:
Rinse two filter papers.
Start timer and pour 100g water in 30seconds.
Stir well for 20seconds.
Put filter cap on by 1:05.
Slow press to 1:45.
Add 50g of 84c water and 50g room temp water.
Stir well and serve.

title: Carlos' XL Recipe
description:
I created this recipe because I love to drink big coffees or share it with a friend.

So, I think is the best way to make a big coffee with a sweet taste.

This recipe includes a 200ml bypass at the end.

Have you tried this AeroPress recipe? Let us know what you think in the comments below!
coffee: 30g, Medium (a little bit finer than V60 grind size), Medium or Medium-Dark Roast
steps:
Rinse the paper filter
Add the coffee in the inverted aeropress
Add 60g of water and stir 15 times during 15 seconds
At 00:30 add 140g of water and stir 15 times during 15 seconds
Place the portafilter
At 02:00 flip the aeropress
Press gently during about 30s
Bypass with 200g of water
Stir and enjoy :)

title: Lucky Morning Cup
description:
This recipe I made for the Qatar AeroPress Championship in 2019 - I won 1st place.

The results will be a bold and sweet cup of coffee that can wake you up.

Enjoy your morning cup, I hope you like it ;)
coffee: 23g, Medium size (V60 style), Natural Process
steps:
In the inverted position, Pour the water against the chamber wall - 100ml for 15 seconds.
Then gently pour in a circular motion - 100ml for 15 seconds.
Gently stir with AeroPress paddle for 15 seconds.
Put 2 rinsed paper filters in the cap and place on the chamber. Push down to release all air from the chamber.
After 50 sec flip the AeroPress onto your mug, swirl gently, and then slowly press for 1 minute until the water is pressed through.
Add 5ml of warm water and 5ml of room temp water.
Stir it with a spoon. Try 1 or 2 sips - if it's still too bold, add a bit of warm water.
Enjoy!

title: Big Ole Iced Latte
description:
If you like creamy iced latte, especially if you use plant-based milk in your coffee - you should give this recipe a go.

This is a variation of the AeroPress Iced Latte recipe which yields a larger creamier variation with the help of flax milk.

If you have tried this recipe? Have you tried other types of milk using this recipe? Let us know in the comments below.
coffee: 36g, Medium-fine, Dark roast
steps:
Grind 36g of coffee and add it to an inverted AeroPress
Boil water and add 120ml to the coffee
Begin stirring the coffee ensuring all of the grounds are mixed
Stir for 40 seconds
Cap the AeroPress with a paper filter and wait another 80 seconds
As you wait prepare a cup with 60 ML of flax milk and 5 ice cubes
When the timer reaches 2:00, flip the AeroPress and press into your milk
I like to give mine a stir, but you don’t have to

title: Fruity coffees by JPanda
description:
This is the experimental recipe that I've made using Ethiopian/Kenyan coffee and the Wilfa Svart grinder.

If using a Wilfa Svart - aim for around second R in AEROPRESS for grind settings and insert the plunger to number three on your AeroPress. I use these parameters because I love being able to taste every note even though coffee is diluted 🐼

For non-Wilfa users, aim for a medium grind.
coffee: 10g, Medium, Ethiopia or Kenya
steps:
Start timer, add 30mL of water
Turbulent wiggle by 10 seconds
Let it bloom for another 30 seconds
Pour 85mL of water
Brew for 1 min (At 30sec, put the lid with rinsed filter on; At 50 sec, flip the AeroPress)
Press for 15 seconds, then add 25 mL of water
Stir before your first sip
Enjoy 🐼

title: Shin's Vietnamese Phin AeroPress
description:
This recipe was inspired by my friend who works as a barista in a small coffee shop.

In his coffee shop Vietnamese drip coffee is the most favourite beverage, and he can't brew with other manual brew methods with his high volume of customers. So, I made this method for him - it yields similar results to a Vietnamese Phin and takes a similar amount of time to brew.
coffee: 15g, Coarse, Natural process
steps:
Pour 200mL water in the AeroPress
Put the cap on
Flip at 4:25
Press from 4:30 to 5:00

title: Béla's farewell coffee
description:
I made this recipe for Béla, the CEO who is leaving our company and one of my best friends. As a farewell gift, I chose an AeroPress Go so he could always have a good coffee wherever he went.

"Béla, kívánom neked, hogy amikor ezt a kávét iszod, akkor jussank eszedbe az ebéd utáni kávézásaink gondtalan pillanatai!"

With this recipe, you can make a delicious, light, espresso-like coffee (2 espresso cups).

Enjoy!
coffee: 18g, Fine, Ethiopian Sidamo Mamo Kacha (light to medium roast)
steps:
Preheat your cups as hot as you can.
Rinse the paper filter.
Add 18g of coffee to your inverted AeroPress.
Add 80ml of hot water, start your timer.
Stir continuously for 60 seconds.
Add the lid, flip AeroPress.
Start pushing, slowly, evenly, strongly.
Pour into two hot, thick-walled cups.

title: 2022 Dubai AeroPress Championship - 1st Place
description: The winning recipe of the 2022 Dubai AeroPress Championship.
coffee: 16g, Medium-coarse (29 clicks on Comandante), El Salvador beans or any medium roast
steps:
Gind 16 grams of coffee - Place two rinsed filters in the AeroPress.
Put the coffee in the AeroPress and tare the scale.
Start the timer and add 30g of water.
Gently mix until you reach 0:20 s ( 10 times ) wait until 0:30.
Add 170g of water ( total 200 g ) and Gently mix until 0:50 ( 5 times ).
Close the AeroPress with the filter & wait until 1:20.
Put the bot/cup on the top of the AeroPress. Flip and press until 1:50 ( 20 seconds ).

title: Freddo espresso
description:
Freddo espresso without a 9\-bar machine.

📝 R﻿ecipe Notes:

  • Don't rinse or preheat the brewer.
  • U﻿se a metal filter.
  • Stir with a plastic spoon, metal spoon absorbs too much heat.
  • I﻿f you use dark roast coffee, use 90°C water and brew 45 sec less.
  • Prepare a coffee mixer or something similar to shake the brew.

H﻿ope you enjoy it!

A﻿ny thoughts ? Leave your comments below!
coffee: 20g, Coarser end of fine area, Light to medium roast
steps:
Put 20gr of coffee in the inverted AeroPress.
Start a timer, add 75-80mL water, aiming to wet all the coffee, then stir with a plastic spoon for about 45 seconds.
Put the filter cap on and flip the AeroPress onto a cup.
Wait until the timer shows 3 minutes. Hold the brewer and the plunger, gently swirl it.
Wait 1 minute (when the timer shows 4 minutes) and press gently all the way down (it will take about 30 seconds).
If you want sugar, now it's the time to put it in. Swirl to melt the sugar.
Shake the coffee with 2 big ice cubes in a coffee mixer or something similar.
Serve in a glass with 2 big ice cubes.
Enjoy.

title: Double AeroPress, Double The Fun
description:
Do you have a spare AeroPress? Or your friend is also an AeroPress fan like you?

Then you have to give this one a go!

Cheffe used this double-AeroPress method in a W.A.C competition in Wuhan, China. It's a unique and fun way to use the AeroPress. Even the judges were impressed by his recipe in the competition.

Basically, Cheffe uses 2 AeroPress, brewing at the same time. One inverted (let's call this one A), one standard (B). B is brewing on a glass.

When A finishes brewing, he presses the coffee from A to B using the funnel that came with the original package. Then he presses B in a normal standard method (which now includes the coffee from A).

There are some special stirring and key timings you need to keep in mind. Read the full steps thoroughly before you brew this one.

Maybe we can't get it right the first time. But that's the fun part of an experimental recipe. Just try it!

P.S Use water with PH 7.2 if you can.
coffee: 20.3g, Medium - Coarse (8 on Baratza Virtuoso), Papua New Guinea - washed
steps:
AeroPress-A: Inverted, add 10.1g coffee; AeroPress-B: Standard, add 10.2g coffee.
Put double paper filters in both A & B's caps, rinse the filters with cold water. Put B on a cup.
Start the timer, add 150g water to A, stir 2 times in a "W" shape.
Add 210g water to B, stir 2 times in the "W" shape.
At 1 minute mark, stir A 3 times in the "W" shape.
Put the funnel on B, then flip A onto B. Press A slowly for 45s.
Remove A and the funnel, stir B 2 times in the "W" shape.
Put the plunger on B and start pressing. Finish at 2:40.
Stir the coffee well and enjoy!

title: Jacoby's 'Pseudo Espresso'
description:
The point of this recipe is to do a twist on the classic "psuedo-espresso" recipe that the Aeropress was first invented to produce... but with better extraction.

“I've only had a couple of varieties that don't take well to this recipe. Go for a nice clean washed Ethiopian or a Kenyan. Makes the fruity notes pop along with having great viscosity.”

Try to finish within 2 minutes otherwise it gets too harsh.

Thanks to the crew @carabellocoffee@carabelloanalog for this recipe.
coffee: 20g, Medium - Fine, A nice clean washed Ethiopian or a Kenyan.
steps:
Place your AeroPress upon your vessel in the standard position and add the coffee.
Pour in 50g of water and bloom - stirring for the first 15 seconds.
Let it sit for another 15 seconds, then add all the water quickly.
Give a couple more stirs then secure plunger in place.
When your timer hits 1:15 start plunging.
Try to finish within 2:00 otherwise it gets too harsh.

title: Tanner Morita
description:
The point of this method is to brew the coffee as quickly as possible. If the plunging is too easy, make the grind finer until you feel that pressing lightly would take longer than 45 seconds. If the coffee is over extracted, stir 3 times instead of 5 less. If under, stir 7 times.

We find that extraction is higher (19-22% EXT) without over extracting. Like most Aeropress cups, this is full bodied. We do not dilute. We have been able to create incredibly complex and vibrant cups with most coffees we have brewed using this method.
coffee: 15g, Medium - Fine, Any well roasted coffee will taste great with this method
steps:
Wash your paper filter in advance.
Set your AeroPress up in the standard position, on top of your mug or decanter.
Add 15g of Coffee to your AeroPress.
Start timer and immediately top with 255g of water.
Stir North-to-South five times and East-to-West five times.
Place plunger in top to stop dripping, but don't plunge yet.
At 1:00, remove the plunger and stir again.
Place the plunger back in and press, slowly, for 45 seconds.

title: Lucky 13
description:
There's a lot of 13's in this recipe, but with so many recipes and ratios this is the easiest way for me to remember everything.

Follow along to enjoy a lovely little warm cup of brilliance (IMHO).
coffee: 13g, Medium / Course, Had tasty luck with Stumptown Holler Mountain (or similar)
steps:
While 'Standard' assembled with filter in. Boiling water through filter into mug, to warm up chamber and cup to a nice cosy temp
30 seconds : Plunge down half way to remove excess water. Invert and remove filter holster
13 grams : coffee (at 13 Clicks on Hario Slim)
13 grams : water and stir till a sandy soak
13 seconds : Bathe, bloom and brew
13 grams : water and stir "for a bit"
13 seconds : Bathe, bloom and brew
130 grams : water and stir "for a smaller bit"
30 seconds : Bathe, bloom and brew
30 seconds : Plunge! Then go do whatever it is you need to do.

title: Smooth Bomb
description:
This balanced and fruity coffee with juicy citrus acidity and notes of tart cherry will finish you off with a lingering syrupy chocolate and molasses aftertaste.

Let me know what you thinkin the comments below ;)
coffee: 25g, Medium Fine, Medium Roast Blend With Balanced Fruity Flavors
steps:
Add 25g of medium fine ground coffee into an inverted AeroPress and shake to level.
Rinse filter with hot water (200f / 93c).
Add 200g of hot water into AP and steep for 30 sec. Do not stir yet.
Stir 20 times in 10 sec.
Place cap on top of AP and press out the air.
Invert and start pushing at 1 min.
Press gently for 30 sec and stop when you hear a hiss. (Time elapsed: 1:30)
Dilute with 40g of hot water.
Enjoy.

title: Spanish Latte
description:
This is a great, simple iced coffee recipe.

The coffee is brewed onto a bed of condensed milk to give it a nice sweet flavour, then finished with full cream milk and ice.

My family and friends love this recipe. The measurements below serve 1.

The recipe recommends using Sagada, a Philippines medium roast, but any medium-dark roast with nutty characteristics should work well.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 16g, Fine-medium, Sagada, Philippines medium roast has nutty and brown sugar notes
steps:
Start timer then add 125ml of 95C water. Stir gently for 30 seconds. Set AeroPress aside.
Place a cup on scale. Add 35ml of condensed milk. Remove from scale.
After 2 minutes, invert AeroPress on the cup and press gently for 20-30 seconds. Push through hissing sound then remove AeroPress.
Stir coffee until condensed milk is dissolved.
To dilute, you may add 125ml of milk. For iced, add 100g of ice cubes.

title: Kimbo Klassik
description:
Whilst my heart desires single origin coffee's all day long, I find myself using some cheaper beans at times to cut costs.

This recipe was developed using "Kimbo Extra Cream Medium Roast" (in fact a dark roast to me) and whilst I enjoy the heavier notes here I wanted to get the most balanced cup out of it!

Inspired by James Hoffmann and the almighty 13g that makes you happy.

Recipe Note:

  • 16 clicks on Timemore Chestnut C3 Grinder, upper end of the pour-over.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 13g, Medium-coarse, Kimbo Extra Cream Medium Roast (works with any cheap darkish roast)
steps:
Add 39g of almost boiling water, stir x 5, wait until 0:45.
Pour water in circular motion until you hit 200g (no stir).
Add the filter and wait until 2:00.
Flip the AeroPress, swirl to get all grinds from the sider, wait until 2:30.
Gently press 20 seconds & Enjoy!

title: Something Sweet
description: Make a sweet cup, with 10 grams coffee.
coffee: 10g, Medium-fine, Medium Roast
steps:
Pour 40gr of water onto the coffee, and swirl until your coffee is all wet (a few seconds).
Let bloom for 20 seconds.
Pour the other 110gr of water till 150gr for total.
Wait till 1:45 and swirl 5 times.
Press down very gently.

title: 2022 UAE AeroPress Championship - 1st Place
description:
The winning recipe of the 2022 UAE AeroPress Championship.

📝 Recipe Note:

- Double paper filter⁠, rinsed⁠

- 27 clicks on Comandante

- Beans used In the competition is Colombia Java El Eden, carbonic maceration⁠. It’s from AlQahwa Al Arabia Coffee Roaster, Sharjah - UAE

Waqar's winning recipe of 2022 Dubai AeroPress Championship is here. It's slightly different, using fewer beans and higher water-temp.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 18g, Medium-coarse (27 clicks on Comandante), Colombia Java El Eden, carbonic maceration⁠
steps:
Start the timer and add 30g of water.
Gently mix until you reach 0:20 s ( 10 times ), wait until 0:30.
Add 170g of water⁠.
Gently mix until 0:50 ( 5 times ), wait until 1:10.
Put the filter cap on.
Put a cup on top of the AeroPress and flip.
Press until 1:50 ( 30 seconds ).

title: Strong Black
description:
In this recipe, you need 21.6g of coffee and fill the water in three stages: 75%, 95% and 99%.

This results in a perfect cup for me every time.

R﻿ecipe Note:

  • Use a typical AeroPress grind (finer than pour-over grind).

T﻿ried this recipe? Lets us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 21.6g, Typical AeroPress grind, Ethiopian
steps:
Grind 21.6 grams of coffee. I use the Aergrind.
Add coffee to AeroPress.
Start a timer, add water to 75% height of AeroPress.
At 0:50 swirl 5 rotations.
Add more water to 95% full.
Swirl 5 more rotations.
Add water to near top.
Begin press at 1:30.
Complete press between 2:00 to 2:10.

title: Low temp stirring recipe
description:
I like my coffee drinkable right away, so for this AeroPress recipe I use a water temperature of 75 degrees celsius.

This causes decreased extraction rate compared to boiling water, so the main task is to find the best way to compensate (increasing time, finer grind etc)

My preliminary conclusion is that the best way is to increase agitation/stirring heavily.

Although I have been trying out different recipes for 1+ years, I still consider this experimental.

I will possibly post an improved/final version when I have tested with more types of coffee.

Suggestions for improvements are welcome (leave a comment below!); that's why I post it now.
coffee: 16g, Medium-fine (15 on Baratza encore), Light or medium roasted
steps:
Prepare filter cap with one or two rinsed paper filters.
Set up inverted Aeropress and add coffee ground to chamber. Even out the ground and level the bed.
For the next three steps, stir in one circle motion each second, using the Aeropress stirrer.
At 0:00 (bloom):Add enough water to make the mixture thin, but not liquid. Stir,
At 0:30 (pour): Add the rest of the water for about 30 s while stirring - this should come to about 2 cm below the top of the inverted chamber.
At 1:00 (main extraction): Continue stirring for 30 s.
