At 1:30 (press): Start pressing, and press slow enough to finish at about 2:00-2:10. If necesseary, increase the pressing at the end rather than at the start. Press all the way through.

title: 2016 Swiss AeroPress Championship - 1st place
description:
The winning recipe of the Swiss Aeropress Championship 2016, as presented by "Die Kaffemacher:innen" on their Youtube channel.

This is a good base AeroPress Recipe, so feel free to use any beans and adjust the recipe according to your tastes.
coffee: 25g, coarse, Everything - it's a basic recipe you can adjust to your coffee and flavor liking.
steps:
Grind 25g of coffee coarsley - think of coarse crystal sugar. Pre-wet the filter paper in the cap.
Put the coffee into the inverted Aeropress, start your timer and pour 100g of water within 20 seconds. If you finish sooner, wait until the timer hits 00:20.
At 00:20, start stirring for 20 seconds slowly and consistently to help extraction (until timer reaches 00:40).
At 00:40 put on the filter cap with the filter on and push out the excessive air - you want to be finished with that before the timer hits 01:00.
At 01:00, invert the Aeropress and push out all the liquid for 30 seconds until 01:30.
You should end up with 70-80g of liquid. Now add 100g of water (bypass) - you may use colder water to reach drinking temperature immediately.
Enjoy!

title: Acidy Hybrid 1:13.333
description:
The idea came from a conversation on Reddit, the commenter stating the fruity acids come from the percolation phase.

By percolation here, it means leaving it to sit in standard position with no plunger to stop it dripping, so the water slowly drips through for a minute or so before plunging.

By using a hybrid of percolation and immersion while brewing your AeroPress, you might reap the benefits that come from both methods.

Have you tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 16-18g, Medium-coarse, Light roast
steps:
Set up the AeroPress in the standard way without rinsing the paper, then add coffee
Bloom: Fill 50ml water stir it and wait 30s
Percolation: Fill the remaining 190ml of water, stir it and wait until 2:00 (1.5 mins)
Press: Add the plunger and press gently for about 30s
Enjoy your drink

title: Terraform Coffee Roasters
description:
This is a recommended AeroPress recipe from Terraform Coffee Roasters, a very popular roaster based in Shanghai, China. I do not own this recipe; all credits go to Terraform.

They also use this recipe for espresso (darker) roasts, using 88 degrees Celsius water and pressing at 1:30; you can experiment with the variables to suit your tastes.

Recipe Notes:

Recommended grind setting - #22-24 on a Comandante C40; or 11.5-13 on an EK43S

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 18g, Medium, Light Roast
steps:
Add 18g of ground coffee to inverted AeroPress
Start your timer, add 50g of water, stir circularly for 10 times
Immediately add 100g more water, stir circularly for 10 times
Twist on the cap with filter and let sit
At 2:00, flip and press until 3:00
Dilute with 50-60g water
Enjoy!

title: Fuller Flavour Profiles Vietnamese style
description:
This is a Vietnamese style coffee for the AeroPress, inspired by a CoffeeAdAstra article: https://coffeeadastra.com/2021/09/07/reaching-fuller-flavor-profiles-with-the-aeropress/

Recipe Notes:

For best results, try using a medium to dark roasted coffee - 30% Arabica and 70% Robusta.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 20g, Fine to Medium Fine (12th click on Timemore Slim), Medium to Dark roasted 30% Arabica and 70% Robusta
steps:
Place a dry filter on and screw the lid on tightly.
Place your dry coffee dose in the dripper and shake left-to-right to make it flat.
Pour about 100ml of boiling water - around ② on the AeroPress.
Stir in a back and forth motion from the complete bottom of the dripper all the way to the top. Avoid circular stirs!
Swirl to level the coffee bed. Close the lid.
Around the 5 minutes mark, give the AeroPress another thorough swirl.
Around the 9 minutes mark (or later), start pressing on the plunger gently.
Add a little bit of sweetened condensed milk, a pinch of sugar or several ice cubes in the summer. Trust your taste!
Enjoy!

title: 2022 Indian AeroPress Championship - Bengaluru Region
description: This recipe produces a coffee with a good body and long-lasting flavour. Its distinct taste makes it highly memorable - with a slightly acidic flavour note.
coffee: 18g, Fine-medium, Medium-dark
steps:
Heat water in a kettle at 89°C.
Place the filter paper in the filter cap, rinse the filter paper with hot water, keep it aside for the meantime.
Grind 18g of coffee to a medium-fine grind size.
Add 18g of coffee to the inverted aeropress, place it on the scale and tear it.
Pour 70mL of hot water in 30 seconds for the initial bloom.
Pour the rest of the water till the scale reaches 206mL .
Stir the coffee with the aeropress paddle (2x left to right and 2x up and down) till there's no coffee settled below.
Wait for 10 seconds and add the filter cap to the aeropress.
Place a cup above the filter cap, hold it in place and invert the entire thing.
Plunge continuously till you hear a hissing sound, then, lift the aeropress from the cup. Your aeropress is ready to serve.

title: A Fruity Perspective 🍒🍊🍋🍍
description: While exploring these certain set of beans I realised they pushed more towards the conventional set of flavour notes but I wanted more and tried something not so usual (at least to me). It’s very important to use a medium darkish set of beans and just let the recipe do its work.
coffee: 15g, Meduim (Hario V60 electric grinder - 18)(EK-5), Medium or Medium-Dark (with some fruity notes only if possible )
steps:
Start the timer and add 20 grams V of water to the 15 grams of coffee in the AeroPress ( Yes, it’s a weird Bloom) .
Mix the water and coffee slurry and flatten the bed of coffee using the stirrer (the consistency will be looking very dense but that’s normal).
At 1:00 add the rest of the water.
At 2:20 put the filter cap and remove any excess air.
At 3:30 flip the AeroPress and give it a proper swirl to make sure all the coffee is mixed properly.
Start pressing slowly and finish pressing the brew until 4:30.
Take off the AeroPress and let the coffee rest for another 30 seconds.
Swirl the brewed coffee and pour into a cup and enjoy.

title: Brew like a squirrel!
description:
This is a quick inverted brew courtesy of Mókuska, a specialty coffee roastery, and café from Stuttgart, Germany. Mókuska means "little squirrel" – hence the title!

This recipe will result in a vibrant fruity cup of AeroPress coffee with an elevated body.

We're using 20g of coffee to 240g of 82°C water.

The grind size is medium. 24 clicks on the Comandante C40 is typically a good starting point Adjust if needed!
coffee: 20g, Medium (24 clicks on the Comandante C40), A light or medium roast. We love to brew natural ethiopian coffees with this recipe!
steps:
[00:00] Put 20g of coffee into your inverted AeroPress.
[00:00 - 00:30] Pour 60g of water and let it bloom for 30 seconds.
[00:00 - 01:00] Quickly pour the remaining 180g of water, put on the cap and flip the AeroPress.
[01:00 - 01:45] Press gently for the next 45 seconds. Stop at the hiss.
Enjoy!

title: Medium Dark Roast Recipe!
description: A perfect recipe for medium-dark roast coffee.
coffee: 16g, Medium, Medium-dark Roast
steps:
Start timer, pour water till number 2 on AeroPress and agitate for 5 seconds.
Bloom for 20 seconds.
Fill water to number 3 and insert the plunger to prevent dripping.
Brew for 55 seconds.
Relatively quick press. No longer than 5-10 seconds.

title: Fast Cup
description:
An easy and quick single-cup method with a minimal, travel-oriented setup.

The fast extraction produces a juicy and balanced cup, with a very smooth aftertaste thanks to the metal filter and the nearly V60 ratio (1:16).

📝 R﻿ecipe notes:

  • I use 30 clicks on the 2022 1ZPresso Q2 (Heptagonal), 1 full rotation from zero. It's quite fine (almost in the espresso range).
  • M﻿etal filter.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 12.5g, Fine, RWANDA Twongere Kawa Coko, washed with double fermentation, light roasted.

title: Aroma and Sweetness
description:
Giving a long bloom allows the acidity and aroma to be better extracted. And a coarser brew lets the drink sit on the sweeter side of the balance.

Feel free to brew longer for more overall balance and complexity.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Use beans that have fruitier profiles and less chocolate
  • Bypass with 20g boiling water

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 13g, Coarse, Beans that have fruitier profiles and less chocolate
steps:
Add 50g water to 13g coarse ground coffee.
Stir and leave plunger on till 1:00.
Add water to a total of 180g.
Put plunger on and let brew till 3:00.
Push and add 20g boiling water for bypass.

title: The Botched
description:
We all had that one morning half asleep when out of nowhere the press seems to be so much easier...

Did you get stronger overnight? Sadly no, you just put your filter wrong and now half of the grounds are in your cup. What a mess.

But let's not throw the coffee just yet 🌚 just put a new paper and awkwardly pour your coffee puree into the AeroPress again to re-filter it.

It won't be as good as your normal cup but... Oh wait... What is happening... Is this...? But how can it be?

It's AMAZING !☕

T﻿ried this recipe? Lets us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 12g, Medium - Fine, Light - Medium
steps:
Put 12 grams of coffee in the inverted method,plunger halfway in.
Start timer. Pour 90g of water over 30 seconds and stir to homogenize.
Rinse your paper filter and put it on the cap, except you are half asleep and put it just halfway .
Wait at least 1 minute, more is better.
Invert your AeroPress and wonder why is it leaking so much.
Give it a couple swirls and start to press. Realize that all the grounds are going in to the cup and you have to re-filter.
Decide you won't throw it away and put all the coffee back in the AeroPress.
Put the filter on properly this time and give it a good stir to homogenize the grounds.
Put the AeroPress on the cup and pull back the plunger a bit so it makes a vacuum and the coffee does not leek. Give it some swirls and then wait for 1 minute.
Press the coffee very gently and slowly.

title: Fresh Orange Iced Coffee!
description:
I recently saw two recipes here at AeroPrecipe.com that I loved!

AeroPress On The Rocks and AeroPress with Fruit Filter and I thought, why not mix the two and have an iced coffee with orange!!

📝 R﻿ecipe Notes:

  • Y﻿ou will need a cocktail shaker or something similar
  • 2﻿50g water + 150g ice + more ice when serve
  • Around 5 slices of orange
  • P﻿ut one slice of orange on top of the paper filter. Make sure you can still close the filter cap
coffee: 18g, Medium - Coarse, Something fruity
steps:
Place 3 slices of 1 cm orange in the carafe, and 1 slice on top of the paper filter.
Put AeroPress in standard position on the carafe, add the coffee in.
Start timer, add 50g of water and stir gently for 30 seconds.
Add 200g of water and wait for 1 minute.
After 1 minute, start pressing. Finish at 2:30
Stir the coffee in the carafe to dilute the oils.
Add 150g of ice to a cocktail shaker.
Pour the coffee from the carafe into the cocktail shaker and shake vigorously for 30 seconds.
Serve over ice and a slice of orange and enjoy!

title: Long Bloom Flip
description:
I'd been using the James Hoffmann protocol and was reading about long blooms to improve extraction. Since the bloom is so long, I went with an inverted set\-up so the water would not drip out during the bloom. I think it gives a nice rounded cup with all sorts of roasts.

📝 R﻿ecipe Notes

  • I use 47 clicks on a 1Zpresso JX S Hand Grinder (30 clicks per revolution), about medium-coarse
  • I add a tiny pinch of salt to the coffee grounds
  • P﻿reheat brewer and filter

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 13g, Medium - coarse (47 clicks on 1Zpresso JX S), All
steps:
Add 26 mL of water, swirl and bloom to 2:00.
Add 191 mL (217 mL total) water.
Stir with the AeroPress paddle for 10 seconds in a back and forth motion.
Put filter cap on and press out the air on top. At 3:30 swirl 3 times.
At 4:00 place your pitcher/cup over the top and flip.
Slowly press over about 30 seconds.

title: La Fruta Madre
description:
This method uses more coffee and a slightly coarser grind to get a nice balanced cup with a clear fruitiness.

Works well with entry-level grinders such as Hario MiniMill (11 - 12 clicks).

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • S﻿tart timer at Step 5

This is my first recipe submission, let me know what you think in the comments below!
coffee: 16g, Medium - Medium Coarse, Light to medium roast
steps:
Place AeroPress on a server jug.
Quickly pour 200g of filter water (99°C).
Stir gently with the paddle four times.
Place plunger on. Do not plunge.
Start timer. Wait 2 minutes.
Slowly and gently press, for about 30 seconds.
Swirl server and pour. Let cool for a minute or two.
Enjoy the fruity flavours!

title: Akuma's Recipe (Tetsu Kasuya Hario Switch Recipe Inspired)
description:
This recipe was inspired by Tetsu Kasuya Hario Switch pour-over method, involving percolation and immersion brewing process. So I decided to give it a try by using AeroPress because it has almost the same capabilities as Hario Switch. The result was a sweet cup of coffee with enhanced fruity notes.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Light-medium roast with fruity and floral notes such as Ethiopian
  • Medium grind size (44 clicks on Mischief M40)
  • A﻿t step 2, you need to add some cold water to the kettle to drop its temperature to 70°C

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 20g, Medium (44 clicks on Mischief M40), Light to medium
steps:
00:00 Add 60g of water and stir gently .
00:30 Add another 60g (120g in total) of water and stir gently and add some cold water into your kettle to drop its temperature to 70°C.
01:15 Fill up to 240g with 70°C water and insert the plunger as fast as you can to stop the drip.
01:45 Remove the plunger and let it drip slowly.
03:00 Put the plunger back, push slowly until the hissing sound.
03:30 Done, enjoy your sweet cup of coffee.

title: Volumetric AeroPress® for 2 (great for travel or camping)
description:
This recipe will brew about 300mls. Enough for a thermos or to share with a friend.  I wanted to achieve a good, even extraction with little fuss. I didn't want to fiddle with a scale, a precarious inverted method, or fumble with creating a vacuum.

It can be brewed with any type of kettle, perhaps a pot, or even a hot water spout at a gas station or convenience store.

What makes the AeroPress so unique and great apart from its ingenious design and compact size, is it creates a cup that is part percolation, part immersion, and part pressurized filter brew with no bypass or gimmicks resulting in a good, clean cup offering outstanding clarity and texture with ease. This technique is designed to be simple and efficient.

I like to use the included AeroPress coffee scoop. Yes I know, GASP volumetric measurement may be astounding to some but this technique is about ease and utilizing the tools provided not technical precision (though they both have their merits). I have found the AeroPress coffee scoop to yield ~17 g of speciality, light to medium roast coffee. Maybe less for darker roasts. If using a darker roast try grinding a bit coarser say medium fine or dropping the water temp.
coffee: 17g, Fine - Medium Fine, Speciality, preferably light to medium roast
steps:
Grind 1 AeroPress coffee scoop of coffee (~17g) — fine.
Place AeroPress paper filter on bottom of AeroPress and add ground coffee.
Fill AeroPress to ① with water right off the boil. Stir or swirl turbulently to fully saturate grounds.
Start stopwatch and bloom :45.
After bloom phase quickly fill AeroPress to brim.
Brew until level drops to ④ and top back up to brim.
At 3:00 gently agitate and allow grounds to settle for 30 seconds.
At 3:30 place plunger atop and press s l o w l y using forearm for style points.
Finish press by 4:30 pressing plunger through hissing sound compacting puck.
Enjoy.

title: Just a good, simple cup
description:
A﻿ good, simple recipe requires not a lot of thinking or complications, just some time.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • D﻿o not press to hiss

G﻿ive it a try and let me know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 16g, Finer than v60, but barely, Light roast
steps:
0'00": The bloom. 80g(1:5), agitate
1'00": The fill. 160g(1:10), no agitation, seal
5'00": The push, no hiss. Push until you get the water out, DO NOT PRESS TO HISS
Enjoy!

title: Dirty thirty
description:
This AeroPress recipe is the perfect balance between sour and bitter, its in the exact middle.

I have used a mix of Ethiopian and Colombian beans, the ratio is 50/50, please mix the beans before grinding.

The grind size is corse to medium, 25 clicks with the commandante grinder.

Let us know what you think in the comments below the recipe :)
coffee: 30g, Corse to medium, Ethiopian and Colombian
steps:
Mix 15g of Ethiopian and 15g with Colombian beans prior grinding
Grind corse to medium (25 clicks on the commandante grinder)
Add 120ml @95c in the inverted AeroPress and mix for 15 seconds
Leave for a minute
Press gently, you should have around 80ml of concentrated coffee
Add 160ml of hot water
Enjoy!

title: Coffee Infused Raspberry Kicker
description:
This coffee infused cocktail really packs a berry punch - recommended pairing with a coffee with strong chocolate notes.

One crucial ingredient for this recipe is the cold drip coffee... check this recipe from PUCKPUCK to make that first, then check back here for the cocktail recipe!

Ingredients for this cocktail:

70ml slow drip coffee
20ml raspberry liquor
35ml burboun
A Martini Glass

See intructions below!
coffee: 38g, Medium, A coffee with strong berry notes
steps:
Add your 70ml coffee, 20ml raspberry liquor and 35ml bourbon into a cocktail shaker
Add plenty of ice
Give it a good 'ol shake
Double strain for a silky smooth finish
Pour into your Martini Glass....
... and enjoy, then come back for another!

title: Closer - AeroPress Espresso
description:
Using a modified Aeropress plunger seal, I was able to get a rich, syrupy, esspresso-like flavor. Other Aeropress espresso recipes have similar strength to espresso, but seem to lack the complexity of a real shot. The donut seal is used to maintain the tamp when pouring water into the cylinder, and ensure complete separation of water and grounds until you begin pressing.

Keep in mind your Aeropress still needs a plunger seal on the end. So buy a new one and replace the old seal on your plunger, so you can modify the old seal.

This recipe uses a metal filter in the Aeropress cap and a paper seal above the grounds and below the donut seal.

Experiment with the grind, tamp, and water amount to get your desired strength and extraction. These parameters will also determine how much force you need to apply, and/or how long the extraction takes.

You will have to push quite a bit harder than a normal Aeropress recipe, so make sure your cup is sturdy (I use a stainless mug) and on a stable surface. Be careful when pressing so the cylinder and cup do not fly out.

To modify the plunger seal: Using an Exacto knife, or other sharp blade, cut a round opening in the center of the seal. Leave the flared outside edge intact. The opening in the center should be large enough to prevent channeling water through the center of the puck, without leaving the seal too thin/flexible to stay in place. Be careful not to cut yourself!

Give this recipe a try and leave a comment to let us know how you go!
coffee: 20g, Fine, Espresso roast
steps:
Place the cap and metal filter on the chamber
Add grounds to the chamber
Tamp grounds
Wet paper filter and stick to bottom of donut seal (flared end point down)
Press the donut seal, paper filter side down, into the chamber until it hits the grounds
Add water
Insert plunger and press to saturate the puck, but stop before the water comes out of the cap
Wait 5-10 seconds
Begin pressing on the plunger again, and continue until the plunger hits the donut seal (~30 seconds)

title: The Ultimate Iced Coffee Recipe
description:
I came up with a new recipe for brewing iced coffee where we basically turn our AeroPress into a cold dripper.

This recipe uses room temperature water, and recommends a coarse grind (eg. French Press). It also includes a 3 pour process, taking approximately 20 minutes in total for the most amazing AeroPress iced coffee

Scroll past the instagram video below for full recipe instructions :)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Kai Peterson - Barista Trainer (@kai_rista) on Aug 17, 2020 at 4:01am PDT
coffee: 30g, Coarse ground coffee (french press grind size)
steps:
Add 30g of coarse ground coffee to your AeroPress.
Start the timer, pour 100g water in (rotate the AeroPress while you pour each time), swirl a little, wait to 5:00.
Pour another 100g water in, swirl a little, wait to 10:00.
Pour the final 100g water in and wait to 20:00.
At 20:00, remove the AeroPress.
Swirl your coffee, serve over some ice!

title: Kruve's Sifted AeroPress Recipe
description:
The Kruve is an easy way to ensure you get consistent grind size before you brew your coffee - this results in a consistent extraction and overall better tasting coffee.

This is the recipe they recommend following when using their sifter - with a bottom sieve of 500 and top sieve of 900.
coffee: 15g, Medium
steps:
Grind 18 grams of coffee
Sift for 30 seconds with the Kruve sifter
Pour the middle tray into the inverted brew chamber
You should get approx. 15grams out after the sift
Start your timer
Add 220ml of water
Rinse your filter while waiting
At 2:20 give the chamber a slight turbulent wiggle and then add the filter cap
Flip the Aeropress and start to press for about 20 seconds
Enjoy!

title: Brew with 2POUR®
description:
Great coffee means getting your brewing method right!

We’ve created our own method to ensure you get the best possible experience whilst using your 2POUR® coffee accessory.
coffee: 30g, Medium, Something nice!
steps:
Grind 30g of medium ground coffee, around the size of table salt.
Add the coffee to your AeroPress® using the upside down method.
Boil 500ml of water to 90-96ºC and add roughly 255ml.
Place the filter onto the AeroPress® and let steep for 1 minute.
Push down on your AeroPress® and watch the 2POUR® take over.
Top up your cups with the remaining water, or to taste. Perfect!

title: Over 50’s
description:
A good start to the Day.

This has become my first brew in the morning.

It’s quick (over and done within 2 minutes) and gets me going.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, Fine, Light roast
steps:
Add 220mL water.
Stir vigorously for 5 seconds.
Let steep for 60 seconds with plunger in slightly to stop dripping.
Swirl quickly then plunge, finish around 2:00.
Enjoy 😊

title: 20g is always a good decision!
description:
Sometimes I like to make some experiments with ratios, brew time, and water temperature. A few days ago I found a new recipe for me and it always works so nice.

I use Commandante grinder on 28-30 clix (no red clix).

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 20g, Coarse, Any!
steps:
Add all coffee in the inverted AeroPress.
Bloom with 60-65g of water.
Stir with a pair of chopsticks to 0:15.
At 0:30 add the rest of the water as fast as possible.
Stir 10-15 times gently, with the chopsticks again.
At 1:00 add the cap on and wait.
At 1:30 invert and plunge until around 2:40 - 2:50.
Enjoy your well-balanced cup!

title: This cup is getting ratio’d
description:
This is similar to the James Hoffman ultimate technique, but his 11g coffee to 200g water just ain’t strong enough for me.

Using a 1:10 ratio I either do 20g coffee to 200g water or, for a larger mug, 25g coffee to 250g water.

Recipe Notes:

  • Dry paper filter
  • 98°C for medium roast, 95°C for dark roast

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 20g, Medium-fine, Medium/Dark roast (200 Degrees Brazilian Love Affair)
steps:
Pour in 200g of water, insert plunger to prevent loss of liquid, but DON'T plunge yet.
Leave to brew for 2mins.
At 2:00, swirl cup/AeroPress.
Allow 30 seconds and then plunged, this could take approx 30 seconds.
Slightly pull back plunger to avoid drips.
Clean up AeroPress, drink delicious coffee.

title: Happy Mistake
description:
I accidentally ground 18 grams of coffee at 17 clicks on Timemore C2, when attempting to make a smaller brew. Crunched for time, so I decided to give the recipe a spin and was very pleasantly surprised.

The coffee from this recipe is very comparable to something from a V60, with an interesting combination of letting the coffee drip through and then plunging towards the end.

This was based on the Kyle Roswell recipe, but scaled up using a 1:17 ratio.

Tried it? Let us know what you think in the comments below!
coffee: 18g, Medium-fine, Light roast (Sakura from Second State Coffee)
steps:
Start timer, bloom coffee with 50g water.
Stir.
At 0:30 add remaining brew weight in a circular motion up to 306g.
Let coffee drip through (without plunger on) and wait until 1:25.
Stir.
Press until water reaches coffee bed (stop pressing with resistance or hiss), finish around 2:25.

title: 8 minutes to delicious coffee
description:
8 minutes in the AeroPress?! Who would have thought? All the wonderful, delicious flavour comes out with no bitterness!

This is a great recipe to set up, make your breakfast or prepare the kids' lunches, then come back 8 mins later and it's ready.

Hope you enjoy!

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, Coarse, Medium roast
steps:
Start a timer, add all 250g of water.
Stir gently and let it brew.
Meanwhile, fill a cup with hot water to warm it up. Rinse a paper filter.
At 8 minutes, empty the cup, place filter on the AeroPress.
Flip and press down gently, stir, and enjoy!

title: Kenya Riaki AA light+
description:
This recipe brings out the oolong taste and tea smells of Kenyan Riaki beans. You'll get a cup that's sweet as wild fruit, bitter as green tea…

A medium-coarse grind is recommended for this recipe - 23 clicks on a C2 chestnut.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, Medium-coarse, Kenya Riaki AA
steps:
Invert your AeroPress, add ground coffee.
Start timer, add 30-35ml of water.
Stir 10x, wait until 00:30.
Put the paper + cap on, flip AeroPress.
Make a gentle swirl until the coffee drops into the water.
Wait until 1:50.
Press for 30-40s.
Enjoy your coffee!

title: Juan’s personal recipe for tasting
description: I love this recipe, it gives you a strong cup of coffee, i use it when i want to taste new beans.
coffee: 20g, Coarse (24 clicks on Chestnut C2), light - medium roast
steps:
Rinse filter.
Put the coffee into the inverted AeroPress.
Add 50 gr of water.
Stir slowly, wait 30 seconds.
Add 50 gr of water.
Stir slowly
Screw the cap, with the AeroPress still inverted, press to take out all the remaining air from inside.
Flip it over your container.
Swing it carefully.
Press slowly.

title: Iced AeroPress Recipe by Alexander Mills
description:
This recipe was posted online in 2020 by Alexander Mills. I'm mainly submitting it so I can save it along with all my other saved recipes here. :) All credit to him!

Note: this recipe uses 150g water and 150g ice.

Source: https://alexandermills.ca/blog/iced-aeropress

His description:
"I prefer this flashed chilled iced coffee method over any cold brew. Brewing hot and pressing over top of large chunks of ice, each drop of hot coffee gets flashed chilled in an instant on impact. The result is a cold cup with big character, not sacrificing any of the sweetness or acidity that you should love in your coffee."

Check out other AeroPress recipes by Alexander Mills:

Championship Cold Water Bypass
Back to Basics

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 20g, Medium-fine, Light roasts
steps:
Pre-rinse two paper filters in the cap to wash the papery taste out of them and preheat the brewer. Discard water and set cap aside.
With the Aeropress inverted, pour 50g of your boiled water into your AeropPress and stir thoroughly. This bloom period will last for 30s.
At the 0:30 mark, pour the remaining 100g of water rather quickly in concentric circles. When your total volume of water is in the chamber, give it one deep stir and then cap your AeroPress.
At 2:30 flip your AeroPress on top of your server and press steadily for 30s over 150g if ice. Stop your press when the AeroPress hisses!
Give your iced coffee a good swirl in your server to exchange those final molecules of heat for some cooler ones and then serve in a chilled glass.

title: Jagursan Kohii
description: Agitation helps us to make a better cup of coffee, good body, sweetness and flavour pronouncement.
coffee: 15g, Medium to fine, Light to medium roast
steps:
Rinse 1 paper filter place it in the cap
Add 15 grams of coffee to the Aeropress
Add 200 grams of 92C water in about 15 secs
Stir back and forth up and down 2x and left to right 2x
Continues this step for every 1 minute mark
After the fourth stir at 4 minutes mark, place the cap, place the server and flip, start pressing all the way through the hiss.
0 out the scale and add 20 grams of 92C water
Swirl the server 17 secs
Pour to your favorite cup and Enjoy!

title: The Upside Down
description: A simple recipe that requires no stirring.
coffee: 15g, Medium, Anything works
steps:
Start in inverted position and add in ground coffee
Pour vigorously to the inside wall of your AeroPress, if your debit is right all coffee should be wet just by this pour
Flip the aeropress at 2:00
Press gently and aim to end at 2:45
Serve :)

title: Like a Dragon!
description:
This one is only for the lols but I thought I should share it.

This recipe doesn't require a timer but instead requires you to know the chorus of Machine Gun Kiss and the karaoke, in-game version of Baka Mitai as they will be our measurement of time.

This recipe is also for those that have a domestic kettle.

I use a Timemore Chestnut X Lite and my grind setting on it is #16.
coffee: 14.5g, Medium-Course, Any Light Roast Coffee
steps:
Prep your Aeropress and ground coffee in the inverted position. Boil your water in your domestic kettle.
When the water reaches a boiling point and the kettle turns off, immediately sing the chorus to Machine Gun Kiss. Just sing it once.
After that, pour 200ml of water into the Aeropress. Stir really gently 10 times. Screw in the filter cap.
Sing the entire karaoke version of Baka Mitai. Not the full version, just the karaoke, in-game version
Flip your Aeropress and then press fairly gently while singing the chorus of Machine Gun Kiss.
You should finish pressing at the same time as your singing. If not, then it's okay.
Have fun, Kyoudai

title: Blue Collar Coffee
description:
Sometimes you don't have time or wish or possibillity to use fancy grinders or fancy coffee. Sometimes You're making construction work in the middle of nowhere, have your lunchbox and electric kettle and a brick of pre ground coffee from small grocery store near that 'nowhere".

This AeroPress recipe is for you.

Just try it.
coffee: 10-12g, Fine, Roasted notes, chocolate with fruity bite, fresh and clear
steps:
Prepare your aeropress, wet filter and lock cap in position, place it over mug (about 330 ml).
Add full measure of espresso ground coffee (aeropress spoon holds about 10-11 grams).
Add 60 grams of hot water and start timer. Stir for about 25 seconds then fill with water to the upper part of "4" mark and insert plunger.
Wait until timer shows 2'15" and start pressing.
Press for about 40 seconds, stop at the first hiss.
Enjoy

title: 17g Light Roast
description:
A quick and easy AeroPress recipe that requires no stirring, no bloom, and no flip.

The original source is claimed to be Skelethon0703 on Reddit. I used Onyx Southern Weather for this recipe.
coffee: 17g, Fine (close to espresso territory), Light or medium roast
steps:
Rinse filter with hot water.
Add coffee, and add all the water quickly.
No stirring. No Bloom.
Steep for 50 seconds.
Press for 20 seconds.
Stop pressing before hiss.

title: Quick and Dirty Cuppa
description:
Not everyone has the fancy scale, and when traveling it might not be practical to bring all your coffee gear.

What follows is my morning routine which works with a wide range of coffees and roast profiles.

T﻿ried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 20g, Between medium and fine on Capresso, Medium-light
steps:
Assemble Aeropress with paper filter - no need to rinse
Add 1 slightly heaping scoop of freshly ground coffee
Place Aeropress over your mug
Slowly add water fresh off the boil till the water hits the 3
Rinse end of plunger with kettle water and insert just barely
At 2 minutes, swirl gently
At 2:30, begin slow plunge. Proceed past hiss to completion.
Add 2 pieces of ice to dilute and bring coffee to drinking temp quicker.
You’re ready to go!

title: Busy Day Big Flavor
description:
If you like bold flavor coffee, this recipe is for you. And it's super simple.

You will need a metal filter and a Fellow Prismo for this recipe.
coffee: 15g, Medium-fine, Dark roast or medium-dark
steps:
Add grounds to inverted AeroPress with plunger just in to the 4.
Start timer and pour water in swirling manner about halfway.
At 30 seconds, give it a quick stir, pour water up to the top, and put on the lid.
At 100 seconds start plunging.
Enjoy!

title: 2022 Dutch AeroPress Championship - 1st Place
description: 2022 Dutch AeroPress Championship, 1st place winning recipe by Maru Mallee.
coffee: 18g, 25 clicks on Comandante, Light to medium roasts
steps:
Rinse filter with hot water.
Grind 18g coffee, and drop it into the Aeropress (inverted position).
Add 150ml of 87C water (agitate softy as you pour).⁠
Stir 20 times.⁠
Put the filter cap, and press any extra air out.⁠
Wait until 1:30, then flip, swirl and tap down twice.⁠
Start pressing from 1:35-1:55.⁠
Add 50ml of room temp water.⁠

title: Short Shot Coffee
description:
Hello, my name is Marek and I am from the Czech Republic. My English is not very good, so hopefully it will be understandable :).

The recipe is purely experimental. I am a hobbyist and new to using an AeroPress and drinking filtered coffee. I wanted to try some espresso-like recipe. For this recipe, I used Ethiopia Sidamo coffee from a roaster in the Czech Republic. I enjoyed the coffee using this recipe so I decided to share it.

It is a standard recipe uusing 14 grams of coffee, 60 ml/85 degrees water and fast pressure. Quick and short.

An interesting thing I've tried here is using a combination of a paper and metal filters. I used the standard method of inserting a metal filter between two paper filters. It occurred to me that if I use a combination of paper and metal filter, I can get a little more pressure through the filters. The reason why the metal filter is in the middle is that the AeroPress is easier to clean. When cleaning, you first tear off the paper filter from the bottom, then take a clean metal filter and finally push the rest into the trash.

Enjoy!

T﻿ried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 14g, Fine, Ethiopia
steps:
Insert the metal filter between two paper filters and insert it into the AeroPress in the standard position.
Rinse the filters with hot water.
Add 14 grams of finely ground, filtered coffee.
Pour the coffee with 60 g of hot water at a temperature of 85 degrees.
Wait 10 seconds, then stir 10 times and press as fast as possible.
The coffee is ready.
Note: The time of 1 minute is indicative and is calculated from the start of adding water to the end of coffee pressing.

title: Semi Pour-over
description:
This pour-over style recipe was created through some experimentation with a multiple-pour technique. This is inspired by the latest winning V60 recipe of the World Brewer Cup.

R﻿ecipe Note:

  • 21 clicks on Timemore Chestnut C2

T﻿ried this recipe? Lets us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 14g, Coarse, 21 clicks on Timemore Chestnut C2, Light to medium
steps:
AeroPress in the standard position with a single paper filter.
Add the coffee grounds.
Pour 50g of water and swirl to saturate all the grounds, wait 35 seconds.
Make three 60g pours, waiting 35 seconds between every pour.
After the last pour, stir gently.
At 3:00 min, place the plunger and press slowly.

title: Tap brewed
description:
Coffee brewed using ice generally presents brighter taste, thus using tap water for a long brew time allows a similar effect.

F﻿or this recipe, use water straight out of a tap, or bottle, at room temperature.

T﻿his is a long brew (8 hours), a great one to setup before bed and have it waiting for you when you wake up.

T﻿ried this recipe? Lets us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 11g, Your own preference, Medium-light roast
steps:
Invert AeroPress.
Place coffee grinds into AeroPress.
Full with water and stir gentle for a few seconds.
Place the filter cap on (leave filter paper out as it may move out of place with time).
Leave for 8 hours.
Remove filter cap and place a filter inside the cap and rinse with hot water.
Replace cap with filter and gentle swirl the AeroPress, thereafter.
Press gently all the way, it takes about 30 seconds.
Enjoy.

title: Global Warming (a very unique brew using Star Anise)
description:
This recipe mixes ice brewing with the traditional brewing of coffee in the AeroPress.

The addition of Star Anise during the ice brewing phase provides a unique spicy taste.

R﻿ecipe notes:

  • This recipe uses a combination of room temp water, ice, and hot water.
  • U﻿se anywhere between 15-20g of coffee, based on your tastes.

T﻿ried this recipe? Lets us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 17g, Medium to fine, User defined
steps:
Rinse filter with hot water and place place into the AeroPress chamber, place the chamber on top of a mug.
Take the ground coffee and mix it with 1.5 tablespoons of tap water and mix in a small bowl.
If you are feeling adventurous add a small piece of Star Anise into the bowl. This works best with fruity coffee.
Take the mixture as carefully drop it into the AeroPress. Wiggle the AeroPress if the coffee bed is not even.
Place 150g off ice gently over the coffee. Since the coffee is already wet the ice will be absorbed uniformly.
Allow the ice to melt naturally.
Once the ice has melted and filtered into the cup, the coffee need skills still be moist, add 50g of hot water.
AeroPressStir vigorously for a few seconds and place the plunger into the AeroPress.
Wait for 2 minutes and press down on the plunger.
Dilute if needed or enjoy as is.

title: A coffee from Twin Peaks 🦉⛰⛰☕
description:
Twin Peaks made me fall in love with coffee, so this recipe is somehow my tribute to this amazing show you definitely should watch!

For this recipe I use a black honey coffee from Costa Rica, but you could use any other coffee from Kenya, Ethiopia, or anywhere else you like.

R﻿ecipe Notes:

  • Grind coffee a little bit coarser than espresso
  • Ideally with honey processed coffee

T﻿ried this recipe? Lets us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, Fine (a little bit coarser than espresso), Medium Roast
steps:
Put 15 g of finely grinded coffee in your reversed AeroPress.
Add 90 mL of boiling water.
At 00:05 stir gently 10 times - it should take +/ 15 seconds.
At 00:20 add 30 mL of water.
At 01:00 put the cap on.
At 01:30 reverse the AeroPress on your mug and swirl vigorously for two seconds.
At 02:00 give a gentle press and stop just before the hiss. It should take 20 seconds.
Cut a slice of cherry pie and enjoy your damn fine cup of coffee.

title: Fruity & Juicy Kenyan Coffee
description:
A recipe specially made for a juicy fruity Kenyan coffee.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Rinsed paper filter
  • Stop pressing when the plunger reaches the coffee bed

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 18g, Medium-fine, Kenyan beans - light to medium roast
steps:
Boil water in a kettle to 93°C (200°F)
Place a filter in the AeroPress cap and rinse it with hot water to remove any papery taste.
Grind 18g of Kenyan coffee beans and add them to the AeroPress.
Start the timer and pour 50g of hot water over the coffee in a circular motion, making sure all the grounds are wet. Allow the coffee to bloom for 30 seconds.
After 30 seconds, pour the remaining 200g of hot water over the coffee in a slow and steady circular motion.
50 seconds in, stir the coffee gently for 10 seconds.
After stirring, insert the plunger and wait until the timer reaches 1 minute and 30 seconds.
Slowly press down on the plunger until you hear a hissing sound. Stop pressing when the plunger reaches the coffee bed. This should take about 30 seconds.

title: Least Variables & Most Consistent
description:
The AeroPress design is deceptively simple, but it can be frustratingly hard to reproduce a golden cup due to the many variables.

This recipe aims to eliminate the variables that are hard to control (pouring\agitation\bypass\pressing.)

Key ideas:

  • “The Press" matters(The timing/force/duration of pressing)
  • Pouring water as fast as possible to eliminate the pouring technique’s effect. You can use a regular water kettle.
  • Press slowly with the minimum force that moves down the plunger.
  • Using the inverted method to minimize bypass.

Use this as a starting point to dial in for your preferences.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Dialled in with light roasted coffee
  • Push plunge into the first number mark on the regular model
  • Preheating is not required. Rinse the filter so it does not come off the cap easily
  • Grind size is medium-fine (I used 13 clicks on a Timemore C3)
  • In step 5, swirling is optional but don't do it in a circular motion
  • Press for about 1 min 15 sec

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 11g, Medium-fine, Dialed in with light roasted coffee
steps:
Invert the AeroPress, plunge in to the first number mark on the regular model.
Grind 11g of coffee to medium-fine (I used 13 cicks on a Timemore C3), put the coffee in the AeroPress.
Pour 180ml off-the-boil(99°C) water in a single motion, relatively fast(<10s). This should provide enough agitation so no additional swirling is required.
Immediately put the filter cap on, and plunge to where water touches the filter so that the ground stuck on the chamber is emerged.
At 1:30, invert the AeroPress carefully and put it on a cup. Let the coffee slowly sink into a flat and even bed. Swirling is optional but don't do it in a circular motion.
At 3:00, slowly plunge with the minimum force that moves the plunger down. Press all the way or stop at the hiss. Pull the plunger back a bit. (I normally finish at 4:15)
Clean the setup and enjoy your cup!

title: Kboom
description:
For a complex, sweet, and flavorful coffee, try this AeroPress recipe using 23 g of coffee and 200 mL of water in an inverted form.

The longer contact time between the coffee and water allows for a more balanced extraction, resulting in a sweeter cup. To enhance the flavor profile - try using freshly roasted and high-quality coffee beans.

This recipe is perfect for coffee lovers who enjoy a full-bodied, sweet, and complex cup of coffee.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Medium roasted African coffee
  • Rinsed paper filter

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 23g, Medium, Medium roasted African coffee
steps:
For the blooming: pour in circular motion above the coffee 60 mL of water and wait 30 seconds.
Stir gently to make sure all the coffee is evenly wet.
Pour another 60 mL of water and stir for 10 times aprox.
Slowly pour the rest of the water over the coffee in a circular motion.
Place the filter on the AeroPress and attach the cap and wait 30 seconds.
Flip the AeroPress onto your mug and press down slowly.
Enjoy your delicious cup of coffee.

title: Standard and Simple
description:
The setup of the recipe is made for medium roasted, washed coffee. It works for arabica and blends arabica robusta in different proportions. However, the setup is subject to adjustment for your type of coffee. Have fun!

Inspired by: Mateusz from Dobra Palarnia Kawy.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Coffee: medium roasted, washed coffee
  • Grind size: Medium-fine. 15 clicks on the Timemore C2

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, Medium-fine, Medium roast / washed
steps:
Setup AeroPress, add coffee.
Start timer. Add water 50mL.
Stir vigorously (4 turns/5 sec).
Wait till 30 sec.
Add the rest of water, 250mL in total. Stir 3-4 turns.
Put the plunger on.
Start pressing very gently and slowly.
Finish at ca. 2:00 min
Enjoy your coffee...
... or adjust your parameters and brew again. Have a good day!

title: 2017 Indonesian AeroPress Championship - 3rd Place
description:
I used this recipe in the 2017 IAC and at that time I won third place.

The recipe is quite consistent and can be used in all types of coffee beans provided.

This recipe includes a bypass, and although the latest WAC regulations do not allow a bypass / dilution, to get a delicious and easy cup of coffee this recipe is worth a try.

Recipe Notes:

  • Use 2 pcs paper filter, rinsed
  • Use coarse grind (34 on Hario V60 grinder)
  • Preheat the AeroPress

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below
coffee: 34g, Coarse, All arabica beans
steps:
Pour 150 grams of water into the chamber for 15 seconds.
Next, stir for 20 seconds evenly.
Wait until 1:00, then put the filter cap on and flip the AeroPress onto a cup.
Press for 30 seconds.
Dilute/bypass with 110-120 grams of water at 84°C, adjust to your taste.
Voila! Serve and enjoy.

title: Standard AeroPress
description: An experimental AeroPress recipe using washed coffee from Indian estates. It produces slight bitter but clear taste notes.
coffee: 17g, Fine (level 2), Washed coffee Indian estate
steps:
Rinse the filter paper.
Bloom with 37mL of water.
Pour the rest (190mL in total) and wait for 2:15.
Plunge till 2:45.
Pour and let it cool for 1 min.
Serve!

title: 2019 Brazilian AeroPress Championship - 2nd place
description:
A recipe from the 2019 Brazilian AeroPress Championship 2nd Place - Abgail.

This recipe uses dual-temp for brewing and bypassing, medium roast beans - washed process, fruity (yellow) and chocolate notes, dense body, and medium acidity.

Recipe Notes:

  • Rinse the paper filter
  • 52 on Breville electric grinder
  • 120mL water for brewing at 80°C (mineral, TDS±120ppm)
  • 80mL bypass at 93°C

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 30g, Medium-coarse (52 Breville electric grinder), Medium roast (washed process)
steps:
Rinse paper filter.
Add 30g of coffee.
Add 120g of water heated to 80°C.
Stir 8 times (straight movements).
At 0:55 attach the filter cap, close and put the cup/pitcher on.
Flip the brewer, and press right away until 1:20.
Adjust the water temperature to 93°C.
Add 80ml of water in the coffee brewed.
Swirl to cool down until 60°C.
Enjoy!

title: Prismo Iced Coffee Latte
description: Just a simple iced coffee latte recipe.
coffee: 22g, Fine (6 clicks on Comandante), Dark Roast
steps:
Grind coffee beans, 6 clicks on Comandante.
Preheat the AeroPress.
Pour the coffee ground in AeroPress.
Pour in 60 ml of hot water.
Stir for 10 seconds.
Wait until 55 seconds.
Swirl the AeroPress.
At 01:00 start plunge.
Add ice cube on separate carafe/glass and put 80 ml milk of your choice.
Pour the coffee, enjoy!

title: Sumatra AeroPress Crema
description: Strong coffee plus a little crema.
coffee: 12g, Medium-coarse, Starbucks Verona or other dark roast
steps:
Invert AeroPress, put 12g of medium-coarse dark roast ground coffee in AeroPress and shake to even the coffee bed.
Put 1 filter in the filter cap and rinse and preheat mug as well.
Start the timer, pour 120g of water, gently mix with up to 10 turns and close the cap.
At 2:00, invert AeroPress and put force in the system to create pressure.
When the liquid has finished going down, release the pressure and finish lightly, letting the crema go down smoothly.
Slide the lid over the cup so the remaining crema goes down. Then mix the coffee with a spoon to enjoy it.

title: AeroPress by Nemesis Coffee
description:
An AeroPress recipe from Nemesis coffee roasters in Vancouver.

This is a simple recipe that produces a very clean cup with filter-like qualities.

Recipe notes:

Grind size: medium fine - 19 clicks on Comandante.

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 13g, medium fine (19 clicks on a comadante), Light: Think Ethiopian: floral, fruitbomb coffees with stonefruit and citrus tasting notes
steps:
Pre-wet your filter.
Place the Aeropress upside down (inverted) on the scale and tare.
Add 13g of medium-fine ground coffee and tare again.
Start the timer and add 200g of water.
Remove the Aeropress from the scale, stir 6 times and screw the lid on.
Carefully press all the air out by pulling down on the Aeropress.
At 1:10, place your carafe on top of the Aeropress and flip.
Press for 20 secs.
Serve.

title: Mediodía
description: Un café corto e intenso.
coffee: 10g, Medium / Fine, Something light, notes of caramel and plum
steps:
Add 10 grams of coffee.
Add 50 grams of water, stir firmly for 10 seconds and let bloom for 20 seconds.
Add water to a total of 140 grams.
Wait until 1:30 and flip the AeroPress.
Finish pressing by 2:00.

title: Dark Roast Americano
description:
This method makes a great Americano style coffee or latte with the AeroPress.

I find the robust flavors develop really well and it brings out nutty and chocolate notes well.

R﻿ecipe notes:

  • Use the provided Prismo metal filter beneath the paper filter so you do not blow out the center of the paper filter when pressing.
  • The amount of beans says 18, but you should get good results using anything from 16-18 - tweak to your tastes.
  • T﻿he first 120ml of water is 90(c), the next 30ml is to be room temperature.

T﻿ried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 18g, Medium Fine, Darker roasts with nutty and chocolate notes
steps:
Start your timer and slowly pour in 120mL of water over 30 seconds making sure to soak all grounds
At 1 minute add 30mL of room temp water
Swirl the Aeropress gently 3 times
At 1:35 press aggressively all the way down to the coffee puck to generate some creme
Add 30-50mL of hot water to taste

title: French Press & Pour-Over Hybrid
description:
Came up with this recipe after trying to brew a coffee that tasted great when brewed immersion style.

You can modify this recipe according to preference - 15 grams will give you a strong bold cup but very smooth. If you would like a softer gentle cup that resembles a pour-over coffee add 12 grams of coffee.

📝 R﻿ecipe Notes:

  • Pre-heat all equipment
  • 2 rinsed filters
  • Recipe works best with medium roast
coffee: 15g, Medium, Medium roast
steps:
Pre-heat all equipment and Place two rinsed filters in the AeroPress.
Grind 15 grams of coffee (not too fine) to inverted AeroPress.
Add 200ml aiming to wet all the grounds.
At 1:00 gently break crust with spoon and give a gentle stir to the top of coffee.
Place cap on AeroPress and gently push out the excess air.
At 4:00 flip the AeroPress and plunge slowly for 30 seconds.

title: The Six-Eleven - A Kalita (non-wave) Style AeroPress
description:
I played with the Aeropress to get the taste profile to match what I make in a Kalita Style 102 Ceramic dripper

On my 1ZPresso Jx grinder, I used a 1.6 grind setting, which I'd consider somewhere between fine and medium. Finer than pour-over, coarser than Espresso.

Water temp was 85 degrees Celsius.

I call it the Six-Eleven, because you take the grams of coffee ground, and the AeroPress concentrate will be grams x 6 and the total outcome will be grams x 11 (or 12 depending on flavour).

T﻿ried this recipe? Lets us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 18g, Medium Fine, Any coffee you'd normally use for filtered or AeroPress
steps:
Grind 18g of Coffee on a Medium-Fine setting and pour into AeroPress (you don't have to pre-wet the single filter).
Pour 36g of 85 degree water and let sit for 30 seconds to bloom.
Pour 72g of additional water and put in the plunger to let steep.
Steep for 1 minute.
Push the Aeropress Plunger so that it takes about 30 seconds to get to the bottom.
Choose the final concentrate dilution by multiplying the total coffee grams by 11 (stronger) or by 12 (weaker).
Subtract the final amount (eg. 18*11 = 198) by the amount already poured in (eg. 18*6 = 108)
Pour the dilution amount (eg. by the calculation example above, it would be 90g).
Enjoy!

title: Fast Brew for Everyday
description:
F﻿or everyday coffee, we all want it simple, fast and delicious. This one might be one of the go-to recipes for your daily AeroPress coffee.

📝 R﻿ecipe Notes:

  • G﻿rind size is medium, 20 clicks on Comandante
  • W﻿ater temp in this recipe is just over 90°C, you can try 9﻿0-95°C depending on your beans
  • M﻿etal filter

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 13g, Medium (20 clicks on Comandante), Medium
steps:
Start timer and add 60g of water.
0:05-0:20 Agitate gently.
0:35 add the rest of water, 200g in total.
0:45 agitate gently for 3 seconds.
Remove excess air, then put filter cap on.
1:30 flip and press for 30-45 seconds.
Enjoy!

title: Zero Fuss Quick “Latte”
description:
This recipe is zero fuss because you don’t need a scale or fancy equipment to achieve a “latte” style drink.

📝 R﻿ecipe Notes:

  • Place plunger right under “4” mark
  • Use 1.5 rounded scoops of finely ground coffee, tap to level
  • R﻿inse paper filter
  • Use water just off the boil
  • Add milk and sugar to your taste

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: -g, Fine, A darker roast, espresso blend preferably
steps:
Wet grounds with water just off the boil. Let coffee bloom for 20 seconds.
Fill to the top with hot water.
Stir vigorously for 10 seconds.
Let coffee brew to 1:45.
Screw lid on, invert, swirl and plunge.
Add milk and sugar to your taste.

title: Daily Driver Triple Blend
description:
T﻿his is quite a unique recipe using a blend of 3 beans and a double press.

📝 R﻿ecipe Notes:

  • All Medium Roast. Costa Rica 10g, Columbia Supremo 8g, Kenya AA 4g ( Sometimes change it up with Ethiopia Yirgacheffe or Sidamo.)
  • Total 22g with 95C 340g spring water (in 2 presses).
  • Grind setting 35 using Breville Smart Grinder Pro (fine).

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 22g, Fine, All Medium Roast - Costa Rica 10g, Columbia Supremo 8g, Kenya AA 4g
steps:
Heat 340g spring water to 95C° - install plunger (in about 2 cm).
Add hot water to 1 cm of top.
Stir with included AeroPress stir paddle - 3 back and forth strokes.
Wet paper filter and install filter and invert onto mug and steep 2 minutes.
Swirl - steep 30 seconds more.
Press gently for 15 sec (about 1/2 press).
Carefully tilt and remove plunger.
Add remaining water and press.

title: 2 Cup Iced AeroPress
description:
With this recipe, I developed my favourite way to have an iced coffee. It is juicy, refreshing, and super aromatic cup.

I would recommend an anaerobic coffee but it's really up to you what you would like to use. Hope you enjoy it.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • 245g water + 100g ice
  • R﻿inse paper filter is optional

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 23g, Medium, Light or Medium Roast
steps:
Add 100gr of ice in a decanter or server and set aside.
Add your freshly ground coffee to the inverted AeroPress.
Add 45g of water, and stir gently.
Let the coffee bloom for 30sec.
Add the rest of the hot water.
Screw the cap with the filter and carefully remove excess air.
Invert the AeroPress to the decanter and let it steep for 3min.
Press gently for aprox. 60sec over the ice until the hiss.
Swirl the server to melt the remaining ice and serve over fresh ice.

title: C4FEN AeroPress
description:
W﻿ith this recipe, we brewed a medium-bodied coffee with a balanced taste.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Medium roast Ethiopian coffee with chocolate note
  • Use a metal filter

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 15g, soft medium, Ethiopia / chocolate / medium roasted
steps:
Start a timer, add 85 mL water, aiming to wet all the coffee during pouring.
Wait 40 seconds, gently swirl the brewer.
Add the amount of water 126 mL.
Wait 1:40 second, gently swirl the brewer.
Flip and press gently all the way, it takes about 30 seconds.
Drink and enjoy!

title: Iced AeroPress | Light Roast
description:
A random experiment that turned into a refreshing drink after a long, tiring day.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Any Light / Light Medium Roasted Coffee - Coffee used in this experiment: Kudiraipanjan Anaerobic 72 Naturals
  • Grind setting: 12-14 on the Baratza Encore
  • Rinsed paper filter
  • 100g Water + 100g Ice Cubes (brewing) + 25g or 50g Ice Cubes in the cup

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 14gg, Medium-fine, Light / Light-medium Roast
steps:
Set your AeroPress in the standard position on a server, put 100g of ice in the server.
Grind 14g of a washed light roasted coffee (12-14 on the Baratza Encore), and put the ground coffee inside the AeroPress and flatten the bed.
Pour 30g of 92°C water and let it bloom for 30 seconds.
At 0:30, pour the remaining 70g, and place the plunger on top until it creates a vacuum seal, but do not press further.
At 1:45, swirl it twice gently.
At 1:55, press it lightly, until 2:15.
Place 25-50g of Ice Cubes in the desired drinking cup, and decant your brew into the cup.

title: Out of beans
description:
Pleasant discovery, after running out of beans.

It's a small - only 4 grams, but a surprisingly sweet and balanced shot of coffee.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Medium roast Kenyan coffee
  • Grind beans to fine end of medium
  • Preheat everything

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 4g, Fine end of medium, Medium roasted Kenyan
steps:
Add 10-15 mL of water, aiming to wet all the grounds.
Swirl for 10 seconds.
Wait 30 seconds.
Add the remaining water.
Let steep for 2 minutes.
Flip and press, finish around 3:00.

coffee: g

title: Mocaeropreccino
description:
A simple recipe for a mocaccino-like coffee. Very well-balanced aromas, quite close to a coffee shop result.

My personal ingredients:

- Light roast fruity/floral coffee (Guji, Ethiopia)

- 7g of cocoa powder without sugar (Nestlé dessert unsweetened cocoa powder)

- 120g of 65°C Semi-skimmed milk or whole milk (froth with Subminimal NanoFoamer v2)

- Grind size: 70 clicks (medium-fine) with KINGrinder K2
coffee: 8g, Medium-fine, Light roast
steps:
Put 7g of cocoa powder in a cup.
Add coffee into your AeroPress.
Fill up with 64g of 90°C water.
Immediately stir for 30s.
Put plunger and wait for 1 minute.
Swirl it a bit.
Plunge for 30s.
Blend coffee and cocoa powder.
Add 120g of 65°C milk (optionally: half foam and half milk).

title: Multiple servings from AeroPress FAQ
description:
The answer is yes - you can make up to three 8 oz (approx. 237mL) cups of American style coffee at a time by brewing "espresso style" with the AeroPress.

📝 Recipe Notes:

  • Coffee: 3 rounded scoops, approx. 14g x 3 = 42g
  • Grind size: Medium-fine, fine drip grind
  • Water temp: 175°F (80°C) for dark roasts; 185°F (85°C) for medium and light roasts
  • Fill water to (3) on the chamber, i.e. 50ml x 3 = 150ml; plus ~570ml to add after brewing

Tried this recipe? Let us know what you think, in the comments below.
coffee: 42g, Medium fine, Any
steps:
Start by putting three rounded scoops of fine drip grind coffee in the AeroPress chamber.
Shake to level the bed of grounds.
Fill up to the (3), about 150mL, on the chamber with hot water and stir for 10 seconds.
Insert the plunger and press gently.
You've now brewed three espresso-style concentrated "shots".
Divide the "shots" into three different mugs.
Add hot water to bring the total serving to 8 oz. (237 ml) each.
Enjoy!

title: A Better Iced Coffee
description:
I found a video on Youtube from Black Tie Kitchen for brewing a V60 Japanese iced coffee. I tried it on the AeroPress and got a wonderful cup!

You need ice cubes!
coffee: 15g, Medium-fine, Fruity or citrusy
steps:
Put 125g of ice in the glass.
Rinse the filter and set your AeroPress in the standard position on top of the glass.
Add 15g of coffee.
Add 30g of water (2x the coffee weight).
Bloom for 45sec (stir if needed).
At 45sec, add 30g water (60g total).
At 1min15, add another 30g (90g total).
At 1min45, 30g again (120g total).
At 2min15 reach for 140g total water (stir if needed).
Once around 2min45, press.
